     v13                                |up, grab the child and his mother, and run for your life to Egypt. Stay there until I tell you. Herod,|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In that timeframe, Governor Herod got a report about Jesus. |

     v 2                                |explains how he can work these miracles.” |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, on account of Herodias, his brother Phillip’s wife, Herod arrested John, bound him, and put|
     v 3                                |him away in jail. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This was because John kept on telling him, “It’s not lawful for you to be married to her.” |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Though wanting to kill him, he feared the masses, because they considered him to be a prophet. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On Herod’s birthday, Herodias’s daughter performed a dance in front of everyone, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |resulting in him making an oath promising that he’d give her anything she asked for. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Her mother nudged her to say, “Give me John the Baptist’s head on a platter.” |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The king became deeply upset because of the oath that he made in front of all his guests. He ordered|
     v 9                                |that the request be granted, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and he sent for John to be beheaded in jail. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of the fact that many have attempted to compose a narrative concerning the deeds which have|
     v 1                                |been carried out to fulfillment among us, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to record it in the same way that they—those from the get-go who became eye-witnesses and custodians|
     v 2                                |of the entire affair—delivered and entrusted it to us, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |it seemed like a good idea for me to follow up after them and write something for you, something that|
     v 3                                |starts from the very beginning and which is completely accurate and in sequential order, Lord Theophilus,|
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that you would become thoroughly acquainted with the affairs which you’ve learned by word of mouth,|
     v 4                                |and that you would know them with certainty.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It came to pass in the days of Herod, king of the Jews, that there was a certain priest named Zechariah,|
     v 5                                |from the Order of Abijah, and he had a wife who was of the priestly caste—and her name was Elizabeth.|
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Both of them were righteous in the sight of God, their conduct, from God’s perspective, was that they|
     v 6                                |complied with all the commandments and expectations of correct behavior. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They had no children, because Elizabeth couldn’t have any children, and both were now elderly.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now during his priestly order’s timeslot in the rotation schedule, he happened to be the one performing|

     v10                                |hour of the incense lighting ritual. |

     v13                                |your wife Elizabeth shall bear you a son, and you’ll name him John. |

     v15                                |be filled with the Holy Spirit while still in his mother’s womb, |

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ACTS Chapter 17  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |After travelling through Amphipolis and Apollonis, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue.|

     v 2                                |his habit of doing, and reasoned with them from the Scriptures, |

     v 3                                |had to suffer and be raised from the dead and that this person Jesus is the Messiah…”The one I’m making|
     v 3                                |known to you.” |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Some of them were persuaded and joined in with Paul and Silas, including a great many of the devout,|
     v 4                                |God-fearing westerners (i.e., Greek-speaking near-Jewish converts), and no small number of the leading|
     v 4                                |women.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Overtaken by the passions of jealousy, the Jews went so far as to recruit some hooligans from the hangouts|
     v 5                                |in the middle of town, formed a mob out of them, and proceeded to cause a commotion. After attacking|
     v 5                                |Jason’s house, they started to try to parade them over to the rabble. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not finding them there, they proceeded to drag Jason and some of the comrades over to the city officials,|
     v 6                                |all the while shouting, “Those guys who’ve ripped through the civilized world like a tornado have arrived|
     v 6                                |here, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the ones Jason has taken in as guests. All these guys engage in activities that violate Caesar’s ordinances,|
     v 7                                |claiming that there’s a different king named Jesus.” |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Hearing this disturbed the crowd and the city officials, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and they collected the fine commensurate for the crime from Jason and from the rest of them and released|
     v 9                                |them.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Wasting no time, the comrades immediately sent both Paul and Silas away to Berea during the night, who,|
     v10                                |after arriving and while being away, went to the synagogue. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Once we were safe, we came to the understanding that the island’s called Malta, |

     v 2                                |sudden rain coming down on us and the cold, they lit a fire and welcomed every one of us. |

     v 6                                |nothing unusual happened to him, and they changed their minds and began to say that he’s a god.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, servant of Christ Jesus, called as a missionary, designated to God’s good news—the Gospel, |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’ll we say about what we’ve discovered about Abraham, our forefather physically-speaking? |

     v 2                                |he has bragging-rights (i.e., he has the right to be proud of and brag about his personal achievements);|
     v 2                                |but no—not with God. |
   N V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Taking a closer look, what does the Scripture say?|
 +PN V 3            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +P  V 3                  VERSES_PROSE: |Abraham had faith in God, and it was credited to him as righteousness|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V 4 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |The agreed-upon pay which the average worker earns is not awarded to him as a favor or as a gift to charity|
     v 4                                |but as a debt which is owed and which he must be compensated for. |
     V 5 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |Contrast that to the average worker who instead of being owed a wage of righteousness believes in the|
     v 5                                |justification of the ungodly and relies on this justification instead: his faith is credited to him as|
     v 5                                |righteousness, |
     V 6 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |just as David too describes the blessings on the person whom God credits righteousness independent of|
     v 6                                |works:|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 + N V 7                  VERSES_PROSE: |Blessed are they whose lawless deeds have been forgiven|
 +P  V 7                  VERSES_PROSE: |And whose sins have been covered over.|
 + N V 8                  VERSES_PROSE: |Blessed is a man to whom the Lord|
 +P  V 8                  VERSES_PROSE: |Will definitely not impute sin.|

 +   V 9 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |So is this blessing upon the circumcised (i.e., those who’ve made a covenant to obey the Law of Moses)|
     v 9                                |or the uncircumcised? The fact of the matter is that we say, “The faith peculiar to Abraham was credited|
     v 9                                |to him as righteousness.” |
     V10 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |So how was it credited? While circumcised or uncircumcised? No—not while circumcised but while uncircumcised,|
     V11 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |and after being credited with righteous, he had the actual circumcision operation done to him, a certification|
     v11                                |of the righteousness of the faith which he had while uncircumcised, resulting in him being the progenitor|
     v11                                |of every believer who traverses from uncircumcision (i.e., them being Gentiles and consequently having|
     v11                                |no covenant with God) to their being credited with righteous, |
     V12 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |and a progenitor of a circumcised person (i.e., a person who’s Jewish and consequently follows the Law|
     v12                                |of Moses) whose righteousness is not derived from circumcision alone but is a result of following in|
     v12                                |the footsteps of the faith that our patriarch Abraham had while uncircumcised.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the promise to Abraham or to his offspring, the promise to be the world’s heir, was not by means|
     v13                                |of law (i.e., a method where one follows a list of rules, with the implication of obtaining righteousness|
     v13                                |from it) but rather through faith-based-righteousness. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To that point, if a law-based methodology is the means by which one lays claim to righteousness and takes|
     v14                                |possession of it, faith has been made null and void, and the promise that was given to Abraham has been|
     v14                                |nullified. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The Law of Moses brings about wrath, you see, but where there is no law (i.e., God-originated list of|
     v15                                |right and wrong), there’s no transgression of that law either.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By this method, righteousness comes out of faith, so that it would be dispensed in accordance to grace,|
     v16                                |resulting in the certainty of the promise to all the descendants of Abraham, not only to those who are|
     v16                                |based out of the Law of Moses but also to those who are based out of Abraham’s faith, who is the progenitor|
     v16                                |of us all, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |just like it’s written in Scripture, “I have positioned you to be a father (i.e., patriarch, progenitor)|
     v17                                |of every nation and of all Gentiles”…positioning him in plain sight of (and therefore getting the full|
     v17                                |attention of) the One whom he believed: God, the One who makes the dead alive and calls things which|
     v17                                |be not as being. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Contrary to hope but resting upon hope, Abraham believed, resulting in him becoming “a father of many|
     v18                                |nations” according to the quotation, “This is the way your offspring will be.” |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not weakened in faith after fully noticing his own already-lifeless body, which by that time had existed|
     v19                                |for a hundred years or so, and the lifelessness of Sarah’s womb, |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |he didn’t doubt the promise of God by being in unbelief but was strengthened in faith instead, after|
     v20                                |giving glory to God, |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |convinced that He who promised is able also to do what He promised. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is why “it was credited to him as righteousness.” |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now what Scripture says—that righteousness was credited to him—was not written for his sake only, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but for our sake too, those to whom it’s going to be credited, namely to those believing and laying their|
     v24                                |trust upon the resurrected-Jesus—our Lord raised from the dead, |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who was handed over and delivered to those who killed him by our sins and was raised by our justification|
     v25                                |(i.e., the process of getting us to where we are acquitted of our sins before God).|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 5  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So having been justified (i.e., examined by God the judge and declared to be righteous) as a result of|
     v 1                                |faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |through whom we’ve also arrived at the point where we have the access by faith to this grace in which|
     v 2                                |we’ve come to stand and boast (i.e., take pride, bask, exult) in a hope of the glory of God.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not only that, but we also boast in our affliction, knowing that the affliction we experience accomplishes|
     v 3                                |perseverance, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the ensuing perseverance approval (i.e., deemed sound as a result of having passed tests), the ensuing|
     v 4                                |approval hope, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the ensuing hope won’t disappoint, since the love of God has been poured out in our hearts through|
     v 5                                |the Holy Spirit who was given to us.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, while we were still weak, even still at the appointed time Christ died on behalf of ungodly|
     v 6                                |people. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, there’s hardly a person who will die on behalf of a person who’s righteous; and maybe someone|
     v 7                                |will muster the courage to die on behalf of a good person. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But God’s own love is endorsed to us by virtue of the fact that Christ died on our behalf while we were|
     v 8                                |still sinners. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now that we’ve been justified by his blood, we’ll all the more be spared from the wrath which is due|
     v 9                                |us through him. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, if we were reconciled to God through the death of His son while we were enemies, now that we’ve|
     v10                                |been reconciled, we’ll all the more be spared, preserved, and kept intact by his life. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not only that but we’ll also boast (i.e., take pride, bask, exult) in God through our Lord Jesus Christ,|
     v11                                |through whom we at this time have received the previously stated reconciliation.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Throughout this all, just as sin entered the world through one man and death (i.e., stagnation of waste,|
     v12                                |joylessness, futility, and destruction) through the sin which entered, and in this way death propagated|
     v12                                |to all men, seeing that everybody has sinned— |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the fact is, up until law (i.e., an enumeration of God’s commandments) was given, sin was in the world|
     v13                                |(i.e., the established order of human beings), but sin is not transacted and counted against a person|
     v13                                |when law doesn’t exist. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That aside, death reigned from Adam until Moses and it also reigned over those who didn’t sin by committing|
     v14                                |the same transgression that Adam committed, who is a prototype of and symbolic of all human beings who|
     v14                                |come after him.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But put that aside. The gift of grace doesn’t operate the same way as the initial transgression: for|
     v15                                |if the many died (i.e., were transformed into a state of spiritual death, resulting in their lives becoming|
     v15                                |a stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction—culminating in physical death itself) by|
     v15                                |the single transgression, all the more did the grace of God and the unrequited-gift overflow to the many|
     v15                                |by grace, by the one man Jesus Christ. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the unrequited-gift doesn’t operate the same way as the affair with the lone person who sinned: on|
     v16                                |the one hand the judicial review which came out of an incident involving a single person resulted in|
     v16                                |condemnation, but on the other hand the grace which came out of many transgressions resulted in an act|
     v16                                |of righteousness.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Put another way, if by the transgression of the singular person death reigned through the singular person,|
     v17                                |all the more will they who receive the abundance of the grace of God and the gift of righteousness reign|
     v17                                |in life through the singular person Jesus Christ. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, just as condemnation came to every person as the result of one transgression, in the same way|
     v18                                |one act of righteousness resulted in making available to every person the ability of to have the slate|
     v18                                |of his entire life wiped clean. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For just as through the disobedience of the singular person the many were declared by imposition to be|
     v19                                |sinners, in the same way too through the obedience of the singular person the many are declared by imposition|
     v19                                |to be righteous. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But law (i.e., the expectation of living up to the standards imposed by a list of right and wrong) slipped|
     v20                                |in, sneaking in unplanned as though crashing a party, in order that the transgression seeded by Adam|
     v20                                |and propagated to the entire human race would multiply; but if the sin which was seeded multiplied, grace|
     v20                                |multiplied even more so, |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that just as the sin which was seeded reigned by the death that it spawned, in the same way grace|
     v21                                |would reign through righteousness resulting in eternal life (i.e., that special fullness of life, one|
     v21                                |which begins in this lifetime) through our Lord Jesus Christ.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 6  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’s there to say about this? Shall we dwell in the sin inherent in all humans so that more and|
     v 1                                |more grace will come of it?— |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t even think about it. We—the very people who died (i.e., were transformed into a state of spiritual|
     v 2                                |death, resulting in our lives becoming a stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction)|
     v 2                                |in the sin inherited by all humans—how will we live in it still? |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or are you ignorant of the fact that any person at all who was baptized into Christ Jesus (i.e., was|
     v 3                                |initiated into a total dedication to Christ Jesus) was baptized (i.e. was initiated) into his death?|
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So we were buried together with him through the baptism ritual symbolic of a total dedication to Christ|
     v 4                                |resulting in death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from the dead through the glory of the Father,|
     v 4                                |we too in like fashion would go about in a brand-newness of life. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, if we’ve become united together in a way which replicates his death, then certainly we will|
     v 5                                |also be a product of the resurrection, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing this: that our old-self was jointly-crucified, so that the body of sin (i.e., the sinful propensity|
     v 6                                |incumbent to our human nature) would be done away with, done away with in respect to us slaving in the|
     v 6                                |sin inherited by all humans: |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for he who’s died has been justified from (i.e., cleared of; absolved of) the sin.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if we jointly-died with Christ, we believe that we’ll also jointly-live with him, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing for a fact that, now that he’s been raised from the dead, Christ won’t die anymore: death no|
     v 9                                |longer has control over him. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, what died died once and for all in the sin inherited by all humans; what lives lives in|
     v10                                |God. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the same way we also consider ourselves to be, on the one hand, dead in the sin, but on the other|
     v11                                |hand living in Christ Jesus.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So don’t keep on letting sin reign in your mortal bodies (i.e., the part of you which hosts carnal desires|
     v12                                |during your life here on Earth) to where you obey its sinful desire, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor put your body parts (i.e., your physical body parts, each part being a metonymy for various activities|
     v13                                |one engages in. In this case, each part is a metonymy for this or that sin, the whole comprising your|
     v13                                |personal carnal signature) in a place where they’re available to be used as tools, mechanisms, or weapons|
     v13                                |of unrighteousness in the sin inherent in all humans, but instead put yourselves in a place where you’re|
     v13                                |made available in God as alive from the dead and your body parts as tools, mechanisms, and weapons of|
     v13                                |righteousness in God. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, sin will not control you; you see, you’re not under the jurisdiction of law (i.e., your|
     v14                                |life is decided by a list of do’s-and-dont’s) but under the jurisdiction of grace instead.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now…shall we sin since we’re not under the jurisdiction of law but under the jurisdiction of grace|
     v15                                |instead?—Don’t even think about it. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You ought to know that whatever thing you make yourself available to be used by—used to the point of|
     v16                                |being obedient to—you’re enslaved to, a slave of either sin culminating in death or obedience culminating|
     v16                                |in righteousness. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God is so good: you were slaves of sin, but you whole-heartedly obeyed what was presented to you in a|
     v17                                |clear, orderly, and systematic way: the particular kind of instruction which has you walking in the righteousness|
     v17                                |of faith rather than just following a set of rules; |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having been freed from the sin inherent in all humans, you were enslaved by righteousness.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The subject I’m talking about is the human condition and human experience on account of the weakness|
     v19                                |of your flesh (i.e., of your lack of self-ability apart from God; of that part of you which has carnal|
     v19                                |desires; of that part of you which fails to live up to God’s standards). You see, just as you made your|
     v19                                |body parts available to be used as slaves in the filth and degradation of carnality and in an artifact|
     v19                                |of sin, namely the refusal to be restrained by any laws, rules, or codes of conduct, which leads to even|
     v19                                |more of the same, in like fashion make your body parts available at this time to be used as slaves by|
     v19                                |the righteousness which is a consequence of faith which leads to holiness. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, when you were yet slaves of sin, you were free with respect to living in righteousness.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what final result did you obtain back then, based on the things which you’re now ashamed of? The fact|
     v21                                |of the matter is that those things end in death. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But as things stand now, on the one hand having been freed from the sin inherent in all humans but on|
     v22                                |the other hand having become slaves in God, you’re getting holiness as your final result on the one hand,|
     v22                                |but you end up with eternal life (i.e., that special fullness of life) on the other. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For the wages of the sin inherent in all humans is death, but the gift of God is that special fullness|
     v23                                |of life (eternal life) in Christ Jesus our Lord.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 7  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or are you unaware, comrades (and I’m speaking to those of you who’re familiar with the operative details|
     v 1                                |of a law-code), that the Law of Moses exercises control over a person only during that person’s lifetime?|
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, a married woman (who owing to marriage laws is under the authority of her husband, who|
     v 2                                |has the legal right to initiate a divorce—but not she) is legally bound to her husband while he’s alive.|
     v 2                                |If the husband were to die, then-and-only-then will she be released from her legal constraint to her|
     v 2                                |husband. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, while her husband’s still alive, she’d be officially labeled an adulteress if she were to get|
     v 3                                |married (and therefore under the authority of and bound to) to another man.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the same way, my fellow comrades, through the body of Christ you too have been put to death in relation|
     v 4                                |to the Law of Moses resulting in you having come into being under the authority of and bound to another—to|
     v 4                                |him who’s been raised from the dead—in order that you would produce aftereffects in God. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, when you were in the flesh (i.e., trying in and of yourself to live up to God’s rules while|
     v 5                                |at the same time beholden to your carnal nature), the passions of the sins pervasive to mankind, those|
     v 5                                |things that, on account of the Law, were repeatedly at work in our body parts (i.e., your personal carnal|
     v 5                                |signature) resulting in the production of aftereffects in death (i.e., in a stagnation of waste, joylessness,|
     v 5                                |futility, and destruction).|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But as things stand now, we’ve been released from the Law of Moses, having died to that which kept holding|
     v 6                                |us down, so that we serve in newness of spirit (i.e. walking in line with and dominated by a regenerated|
     v 6                                |human spirit, which is in communion with the Holy Spirit) and not oldness of letter (i.e., a strict,|
     v 6                                |literal, exacting interpretation of the verbatim Law of Moses, along with a grueling, rigid adherence|
     v 6                                |done the “old way”—out of a person’s self-ability).|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’s there to say about this? Are we to conclude that the Law of Moses is characteristic of and|
     v 7                                |has the quality and nature of sin?—Don’t even think about it—on the contrary I would not have come to|
     v 7                                |know, recognize, and understand the sin pervasive to mankind if not through law (i.e., by conducting|
     v 7                                |my life under the weight of a long list of God-ordained rules); for indeed I would’ve come to know this|
     v 7                                |first-hand had not the Law of Moses kept on telling me over and over, “Thou shalt not covet such-and-such.”|
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Sin took advantage of the situation through the commandment “thou shalt not covet” and worked utterly|
     v 8                                |in me every sort of coveting imaginable: you see, apart from law (i.e., being forced to obey a list of|
     v 8                                |rules) sin is dead. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the past I was alive and living apart from law; but the commandment came and the sin of coveting which|
     v 9                                |I just mentioned sprang to life; |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I died. It became evident in me that the commandment—the same one leading to life—was leading to death.|
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To be more specific, the sin of coveting through the commandment took advantage of the situation, fooled|
     v11                                |me completely, and killed me (i.e., caused me to die spiritually) by this. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Consequently, the Law of Moses is indeed holy, and the commandment “thou shalt not covet” is holy and|
     v12                                |just and good.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So the thing which is good became a mechanism of death in me, right?—Don’t even think about it; on the|
     v13                                |contrary, in order that the nature and devastation of sin would become apparent, sin utterly worked death|
     v13                                |through the good in me, so that the sin of coveting would reach its maximal efficacy through the commandment|
     v13                                |“thou shalt not covet.” |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we know for a fact that the Law is intrinsically spiritual; I am fleshly (i.e., the nature of|
     v14                                |my physical body is that it is susceptible to carnal temptations, and that part of me does not want to|
     v14                                |serve God), having been sold by the sin pervasive to mankind: |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I don’t understand nor do I recognize what it is that I’m getting done; the fact of the matter is, I’m|
     v15                                |not putting into practice what I want—I’m doing what I hate instead. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if I’m doing what I don’t want to, I concur with the Law of Moses, concurring that it’s good. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |At this point, though, it’s no longer me personally accomplishing this but rather the sin which inhabits|
     v17                                |me.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, I know for a fact that good does not inhabit me, that is, in my flesh (i.e. in my human, carnal|
     v18                                |nature); for the wanting is present in me, at hand ready to jump in, but getting the good done is not|
     v18                                |happening. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, I’m not doing the good that I want to do, but instead, I’m doing the bad which I don’t want|
     v19                                |to do and doing it on a day-to-day basis. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if what I don’t want to do is the thing that I’m doing, It’s no longer me producing the finished|
     v20                                |product but the sin which inhabits me is producing it instead. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m discovering the Law of God (i.e., the principle that one should do right and live according to God’s|
     v21                                |will), then, with the wanting in me to do the good, because the bad is present in me, ready to rear its|
     v21                                |ugly head; |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, I delight in the Law of God with respect to the inner-person, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but I see another law (i.e., a different principle) in my body parts (i.e., in my unique carnal signature)|
     v23                                |waging war against the law of my mind (i.e. against the principles by which my mind operate), defeating|
     v23                                |me and making me a prisoner of the sin which exists in my body parts. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What a miserable person I am: who’ll rescue me from this body which is rooted in death?— |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God is so good through Jesus Christ our Lord!—So then me—on the one hand I’m enslaved in mind to a law|
     v25                                |of God (i.e., to a principle set in place by God), but on the other hand I’m enslaved in flesh to a law|
     v25                                |of sin (i.e., to a principle of sin caused by carnality).|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||
    [ ROM Chapter 7 has no footnotes ]

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 8  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Therefore, there’s nothing of condemnation now with those in Christ Jesus: |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The law of the spirit of life (i.e., the principle of living a spiritual life in communion with the Holy|
     v 2                                |Spirit) set you free from the law of the sin which afflicts mankind and the ensuing death (i.e. the principle|
     v 2                                |of sin coming about due to our human nature and the resulting stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility,|
     v 2                                |and destruction). |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the inability of the Law of Moses in that it was continually weak through the flesh (i.e., through|
     v 3                                |human ability alone apart from God and aggravated by human carnality), God sent His very-own son in sinful-flesh|
     v 3                                |form and, in regard to sin, condemned the sin in the flesh, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the decrees of the Law of Moses would be fulfilled in us, in those who’re not going about their|
     v 4                                |day-to-day business according to flesh (i.e., according to their own ability apart from God and according|
     v 4                                |to their carnal nature) but rather according to spirit (i.e., according to a spiritual life, a life in|
     v 4                                |communion with the Holy Spirit). |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For those whose existence is in accordance with the nature of the flesh think about the things of the|
     v 5                                |flesh; those whose existence is in accordance with spirit (i.e. with living a spiritual life) think about|
     v 5                                |the things of the Spirit. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that the flesh-mindset is death; the mindset of the spirit is life and peace.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On account of the mercies of God, I beseech you, comrades, to present your bodies an alive, holy, and|
     v 1                                |acceptable (“acceptable” as though it complies with something analogous to the requirements in the Old|
     v 1                                |Testament for the animals to be sacrificed) sacrifice (like a sacrificial animal) to God, performing|
     v 1                                |your religious ritual, one which constitutes worship. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And be not conformed to the lifestyle of this age, but be transformed on the outside by what’s on the|
     v 2                                |inside by the renewing of the mind instead, resulting in you continuously approving as the result of|
     v 2                                |examination what the will of God is, the good will of God, the acceptable will of God, and the perfect|
     v 2                                |will of God.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In addition, through the grace given to me I’m telling every one of you all not to let your minds stray|
     v 3                                |and be thinking loftier thoughts, thoughts where you think more highly of yourself, than you ought be|
     v 3                                |thinking, but be sound-minded (i.e., come down to earth, straighten your head out, and get rid of those|
     v 3                                |lofty thoughts) instead, as God has allocated an area of responsibility for every person. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, just as there’re many parts to any given body, but all the parts don’t serve the same purpose,|
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |similarly, we the many parts are one body in Christ, and a member of one another from an individual perspective.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now having gifts according to the grace (i.e., the giver giving not based on the receiver meriting it|
     v 6                                |but based on the giver’s generosity; giving with no expectation of receiving anything in return; giving|
     v 6                                |something freely and therefore irrevocably) given to us diversely, whether the gift be prophecy (i.e.,|
     v 6                                |speaking the utterances of God) let the prophesying be done according to the allocation of responsibility;|
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |whether being in charge of a particular area of ministry and serving in that area, let the same be applied|
     v 7                                |to the service; whether teaching, let the same be applied to the teaching; |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |whether assistance, advocacy, counseling, and encouraging, let the same be applied to the assistance,|
     v 8                                |etc.; whether giving, let the same be applied in singleness (i.e., in simplicity: straightforward, without|
     v 8                                |hesitancy, hidden agendas, or internal conflicts); whether taking the lead, let the same be applied with|
     v 8                                |pep, diligence, and self-motivation; whether being merciful, let the same be applied in cheerfulness.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  ROM Chapter 13  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let all people from all walks of life submit to the overarching authorities; the fact is, there’s no|
     v 1                                |authority-structure except what’s been put there by God, and those that exist have been arranged, organized,|
     v 1                                |and put into place by God into the state in which they exist, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that any given person who opposes the authority that’s in place has taken a stand against the way|
     v 2                                |that God decides to organize and arrange things; the ones who’ve taken a stand in opposition to the authorities|
     v 2                                |in place will be judged (i.e., arrested, prosecuted, convicted, and incarcerated by the criminal justice|
     v 2                                |system) for doing so. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, those who do good have no need to be afraid of rulers; but those who do bad need to be afraid.|
     v 3                                |Do you want to have no fear of the authorities?—do good, and you’ll be applauded by them: |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the person in authority is God’s servant for you in a positive way. But if you were to live the life|
     v 4                                |of crime, be afraid: the authorities have the wherewithal to forcibly and violently impose their will|
     v 4                                |upon you—and won’t hesitate to use it. In fact, the authorities are God’s servants to dole out wrath|
     v 4                                |upon the stereotypical criminal.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Putting it all together, you’ve got to submit to the authorities, not just because of the wrath they|
     v 5                                |could potentially inflict but also because you should be keeping a clean conscience. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, this is also a reason why you pay taxes: they’re ministers (i.e., officers, constables, judges,|
     v 6                                |etc.) of God employed full-time at this, and their salary is paid out of tax revenue. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pay all the taxes that you’re on the hook to pay: tax to the taxman, tolls at the tollgate, customs at|
     v 7                                |the customhouse, reverence—fear even—to the one who instills fear, honor to the one who should be honored.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t owe anyone anything except to love one another: he who loves another person has fulfilled law (i.e.,|
     v 8                                |has satisfied the mandates of any list of godly rules). |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this end, the commandments, “Thou shalt not commit adultery,” “Thou shalt not murder,” “Thou shalt|
     v 9                                |not steal,” “Thou shalt not covet,” and if there’s any other commandment I should’ve included, it’s summed|
     v 9                                |up by one statement, “Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.” |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The love that you show to the typical neighbor doesn’t do anything bad; so then, love is a fulfillment|
     v10                                |of law.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ll add this to what I’ve said. You know what time it is, that it’s time for us to wake up, for now|
     v11                                |our salvation is closer than when we first became believers. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The night wanes, daylight approaches, so put away the deeds of darkness; put on the armor of the light.|
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Like the way people carry themselves during the day, go about behaving appropriately and properly, not|
     v13                                |with loud partying, drunkenness, or sleeping around and unrestrained indulgence in immoral, physical|
     v13                                |pleasures, nor strife, discord, contention and the ensuing passions. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Instead, clothe yourselves in the Lord Jesus Christ and make no provision to indulge the desires of the|
     v14                                |flesh (i.e., one’s carnal nature).|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Accept the person who’s struggling in the Faith the way he is without resolving the disagreements over|

     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t let the one who believes he’s permitted to eat anything despise the one who doesn’t, and don’t|
     v 3                                |let the one who won’t eat everything judge the one who does; you see, God has accepted this person.|

     v 4                                |the nod of approval to continue doing what he’s doing or be reprimanded and forced to amend his behavior)|
     v 4                                |by his own boss. And stand he will, for the boss—the Lord—is able to pick him up off the ground and stand|
     v 4                                |him to his feet.|

     v 5                                |another person decides that all days are the same and so none stands out above the others—let each person|
     v 5                                |work it all out in his own mind. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The one who thinks about what days should be considered holy thinks the day he has in mind should be|

     v 8                                |if we so happen to live and so happen to die, we are of the Lord (i.e., we are a part of, are derived|
     v 8                                |from, the Lord). |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, Christ died and came back to life again to arrive at this point: in order to assume lordship|

     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But he who’s weighing point and counterpoint deciding if he’d chance eating some food has already reached|
     v23                                |the point where he’s condemned (i.e., objectively guilty of wrong-doing), since that’s not a product|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From Paul, who has the calling of an apostle (a missionary) of Christ Jesus through the will of God,|
     v 1                                |and his comrade Sosthenes—|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To God’s church which exists in Corinth, those set apart by Christ Jesus from the unbelievers in this|
     v 2                                |world, those called to be holy in unison with those everywhere who are calling upon the name of our Lord|
     v 2                                |Jesus Christ (i.e., those invoking Jesus’s promises, his authority, and his favorable disposition)—|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When it comes to you, I’m always thanking my God for the grace He’s given you in Christ Jesus, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because in him you’ve been enriched in all things, in every concept imaginable and in all sorts of knowledge|
     v 5                                |and understanding, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |just as the testimony of Christ (i.e., the official statement about Christ) has been both made firm and|
     v 6                                |has been confirmed in you, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that you’re not lacking in any Holy Spirit-generated gift, ministry, or manifestation of the Holy|
     v 7                                |Spirit, eagerly awaiting the revelation of Christ Jesus our Lord, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who will also establish us until the end of time so that we’re blameless in the day of our Lord Jesus|
     v 8                                |Christ. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Faithful is the God through whom we’ve been called into the fellowship of His son Jesus Christ our Lord.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I appeal to you, comrades, through the name (i.e., the authority) of our Lord Jesus Christ, pleading|
     v10                                |to you that you would always be on the same page and that there not be divisions among you, but that|
     v10                                |you’d be fitted and mended together with the same mind and with the same knowledge and understanding.|
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard and concerning you, it’s been made clear to me by Chloe’s family and her servants, my|
     v11                                |dear comrades, that there’s strife going on between you. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ll say this: some of you say “I’m Paul’s devotee exclusively” while others say “I’m Apollos’s devotee|
     v12                                |exclusively” or “I’m Peter’s devotee exclusively”, or “I’m Christ’s devotee exclusively.” |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Has Christ been divided up into pieces? Paul wasn’t crucified on your behalf, was he? Or, were you baptized|
     v13                                |(i.e., initiated into the Christian faith) on Paul’s sole authority to be a member of Paul’s camp? |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Thank God I didn’t baptize any of you except Crispus and Gaius, |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |lest anyone say that they were baptized on my sole authority to be a member of my camp. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now I did baptize Stephanas’s family and servants, but as far as the rest of you, I’m not absolutely|
     v16                                |sure if I baptized anyone else. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, Christ didn’t send me to go about baptizing in order to build a camp of my own followers but|
     v17                                |to go about evangelizing instead, not in wisdom which comes out of a message, so that the cross of Christ|
     v17                                |wouldn’t be rendered ineffectual.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The message of the cross, you see, is stupidity to those who are lost and dying on the one hand, but|
     v18                                |to those who are being saved (i.e., being rescued from spiritual, moral, and physical calamity), it’s|
     v18                                |the power of God. |
   N V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For it’s written in the Old Testament:|
 +PN V19            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V19                  VERSES_PROSE: |I’ll destroy the wisdom of the wise,|
 +P  V19                  VERSES_PROSE: |And I’ll annul the understanding of those who understand|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V20 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |Where’s the wise man? Where’s the scholar? Where’s this generation’s premier debater? Hasn’t God turned|
     v20                                |this world’s wisdom into stupidity?|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, by the wisdom of God, since the world through its wisdom didn’t come to recognize, discern,|
     v21                                |understand, or know God, God was more than happy through the stupidity of what was preached to save those|
     v21                                |who made the decision to believe. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Forasmuch as Jews chase after stupendous miracles and Westerners chase after wisdom, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |we, on the other hand, preach a crucified-Christ; for Jews it’s the root-cause of the failure caused|
     v23                                |by disobedience on the one end of the stick, on the other end of the stick, for Westerners it’s stupidity,|
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but to them who are “the Called” (i.e., those whom God has summoned to be His people and who have heeded|
     v24                                |the summons), Jews and Westerners alike, Christ is God’s power and God’s wisdom, |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since the “stupidity” of God is wiser than the wisdom to be found in mankind, and the “weakness” of God|
     v25                                |is stronger than the strength to be found in mankind.|
 +   V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, consider your group “the Called”: if one looks at their backgrounds only, not very many|
     v26                                |of them are wise, not many powerful, not many from high-society families or nobility. |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No, God’s chosen the stupid things of the world to put to shame the wise things, and the weak things|
     v27                                |of the world to put to shame the strong, |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and God’s chosen the lowly born and those things which are contemptuous—He’s chosen the things that don’t|
     v28                                |exist to abolish what does, |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that any and every human endeavor or accomplishment apart from God can’t be presented proudly before|
     v29                                |Him in the statement, “See—look what I did!” |
     V30              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But what’s come out of Him is that you’re melded with Christ Jesus, who became to us wisdom from God,|
     v30                                |righteousness, and likewise holiness and redemption (i.e., the recovery of what you once had), |
     V31              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so it’d turn out just like it’s written in the Old Testament, “Let the one who brags about his accomplishments|
     v31                                |brag in the Lord.”|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When I went and visited you, comrades, I didn’t go there and use heady, intellectual language and sublime|

     v 4                                |a powerful demonstration of the Spirit that’s difficult to describe if you’ve never experienced it, |

     v 6                                |who are being rendered ineffective and brought to nothing— |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |instead we speak words of God’s wisdom in a mystery, a wisdom which has been hidden up to this point,|
     v 7                                |a wisdom which God knew beforehand in eternity past and intended for our glory, |

     v 8                                |wouldn’t have crucified the Lord of Glory. |

 +PN V 9            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||

     v11                                |details and intentions of God except the Spirit of God.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we have not received the spirit of the world but rather the Spirit who proceeds out of God, so that|
     v12                                |we would know firsthand what God has given to us as an expression of His grace— |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and what was given to us is also that which we speak, not speaking in human teachings consisting of words|
     v13                                |of wisdom but rather in teachings of the Spirit consisting of the fitting together nicely of Holy Spirit-related|
     v13                                |content with other Holy Spirit-related content. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |A person who’s dominated by his mind, intellect, or emotions instead of by his spirit won’t receive the|

     v14                                |or recognize them because such things are spiritually examined and decided as a result. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the spiritual person examines and decides all things, but he himself isn’t examined and his life|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But I, comrades, wasn’t able to speak to you like I would to people attuned to and dominated by spiritual|
     v 1                                |things but rather like I would to people attuned to and dominated by fleshly things (i.e., things that|
     v 1                                |have to do with our lives in the natural, even touching our carnal appetites), same as I would to those|
     v 1                                |who are babies in Christ. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I fed you milk, not solid food, as you were not yet able to digest solid food, having not been weaned|
     v 2                                |off milk—but even now you still can’t handle solid food; |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You’re still fleshly, you see: where there’s jealousy and strife still found among you, are you not fleshly,|
     v 3                                |and do you not leads lives dictated by the undesirable human tendencies?|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For example, when one of you says, “I’m Paul’s devotee exclusively,” and another of you says, “I’m Apollos’s|
     v 4                                |devotee exclusively,” are you not being dominated by your undesirable human tendencies? |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So who is Apollos? Who is Paul—they’re ministers, and you came to believe in Christ through their ministries,|
     v 5                                |and all the steps involved and the ministries that were a part of leading you to Christ happened to each|
     v 5                                |person as the Lord granted that it happen. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I planted the seed, Apollos watered it, but it was God who made it grow, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that neither the one doing the planting nor the one doing the watering is the most important part|
     v 7                                |of the process, but God who makes things grow is the most important. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The one who does the planting and the one who does the watering are on the same team, and each will receive|
     v 8                                |an individual-specific wage according to his own individual labor.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re God’s coworkers, you see, laboring together in God’s field, whereas you’re the building-project|
     v 9                                |which God’s constructing, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |being constructed according to the grace of God which was given to me as a judicious chief architect|
     v10                                |and principal contractor. Accordingly, I laid the foundation, and another subcontractor came after me|
     v10                                |and built the structure on top of the foundation, but let each subcontractor look over what he built,|
     v10                                |to ensure that it was done correctly. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that no one can lay any other foundation other than the one which has been|
     v11                                |laid, which foundation is Jesus Christ. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if some subcontractor builds upon the foundation by putting in place gold, silver, gemstones (i.e.,|
     v12                                |the subcontractor did a high-quality job), wood, hay, or straw (i.e., the subcontractor did a low-quality|
     v12                                |job) structures upon that foundation, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the quality of the work that that particular subcontractor did will become apparent to everyone, since|
     v13                                |some cataclysmic event will eventually occur that is enormously stressful to the structure, making its|
     v13                                |true strengths and deficiencies abundantly clear to everyone, since these true strengths and weaknesses|
     v13                                |are revealed by fire (i.e., intense stress), and the fire will determine what kind of job was done by|
     v13                                |putting it through the wringer. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If any of the built-up construction remains, the subcontractor will get paid; |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |if any of the built-up construction is burned up, he’ll lose money on the project, but he’ll be spared|
     v15                                |of personal ruin, but he’ll lose his entire investment through the ordeal.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t you know that you are a temple of God and that the Spirit of God has taken up residence in you?|
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If someone trashes, ruins, or destroys the temple of God, God will trash that guy. The temple of God—the|
     v17                                |very thing that you are—is holy, you see.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let no one fool himself utterly in this regard: if any of you considers himself to be wise in this age,|
     v18                                |let him become stupid, so that he would become wise; |
   N V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for the wisdom of this world is stupidity to God. In fact, it’s written in the Old Testament:|
 +PN V19            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +P  V19                  VERSES_PROSE: |He’s catching the wise in their subtle trickery|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 + N V20 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |And another verse says,|
 +PN V20            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V20                  VERSES_PROSE: |The Lord understands the arguments of the wise—|
 +P  V20                  VERSES_PROSE: |He knows that they’re futile|
 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V21 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |So then, let no one be charged up and beam with pride over people that they’re devotees of. The fact|
     v21                                |of the matter is, all of you— |
     V22 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |whether we’re referring to Paul, Apollos, or Peter—or whether we’re talking about life, death, the past,|
     v22                                |or the future— |

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Chapter 4  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let a person frame his perception of us this way: that we’re attendants of Christ and stewards of the|
     v 1                                |mystery of God. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In regard to stewardship, it’s a minimum requirement that a person who’s a steward be found faithful.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But it’s not a big deal for me to be examined and then judged by you or by any human tribunal for that|
     v 3                                |matter, nor do I judge myself in self-examination. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, I’m not self-conscious about anything I might’ve done wrong, but—no—I haven’t been exonerated|
     v 4                                |of all wrong-doing in this stewardship of mine, but the Lord is the one who examines and judges me, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that you won’t judge me before the timeframe set aside for judgment, that is until the Lord happens|
     v 5                                |to come, who in the course of judging will also will illuminate the hidden things of darkness and will|
     v 5                                |put the plans, strategies, intentions, and collaborations of the hearts out in the open, and at that|
     v 5                                |time the praise from God to each person for what he did right will appear.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But because of you, comrades, I made the change and applied these things to Apollos and me, so that through|
     v 6                                |our example you would learn the meaning of “Don’t be so high-and-mighty that the stuff that’s written|
     v 6                                |in the Bible somehow doesn’t apply to you,” so that your egos don’t become overly-inflated, with one|
     v 6                                |person thinking himself to be superior in understanding something to the one who explained that something|
     v 6                                |to him in the first place, both opposed to someone who has a different opinion. |
   N V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, who determines what all the different points of view are among you and sorts you into categories|
     v 7                                |based on viewpoint?|
 +P  V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What do you have that you didn’t go out and get? And if you got the things you decided to get, why do|
     v 7                                |you carry on like you never got them? |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You’ve already gotten plenty enough—you’re already rich—you live like kings when you’re apart from us—it|
     v 8                                |sure would be great if you actually became kings, so that we could live like kings together with you.|
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, I’m thinking that God made an exhibit out of us—the apostles, the lowliest of people—putting|
     v 9                                |us on display, making us appear to everyone as though we’re men who’re condemned to death, since we became|
     v 9                                |a spectacle to the world, to angels, and to all of mankind. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We are idiots on account of Christ, but you are logical and sensible in Christ; we are weak, you are|
     v10                                |strong; we are glorious, you are dishonored. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Up until this very moment in time, we went hungry and thirsty, had no clothes to wear, were beaten, were|
     v11                                |homeless, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and toiled doing hard manual labor. While being abused, we bless; while being persecuted, we endure;|
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |while being slandered, we speak softly. Up until now, we’ve been treated like we’re the scum of the world;|
     v13                                |like we’re everyone’s garbage.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m not writing these things to shame you or to put you on a guilt trip, rather I’m writing to you as|
     v14                                |though you’re my children, ones who are dear to me, and I’m admonishing, warning, and instructing you|
     v14                                |as such. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, even if you had a million tutors in Christ, you still wouldn’t have many fathers (i.e., those|
     v15                                |who were instrumental in your conversion) in Christ, seeing that I begot you in Christ Jesus through|
     v15                                |the Gospel. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So I’m pleading with you: get to where you imitate me. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of this desire on my part, I sent you Timothy, who is my dear child in Christ and who’s faithful|
     v17                                |in the Lord, who’ll remind you to imitate the way I do things in Christ Jesus, just like I teach everyone|
     v17                                |in churches everywhere.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |As I’m not heading in your direction to visit you at the moment, some of you have acquired inflated egos.|
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if it was the Lord’s will, I’d leave immediately and travel as quickly as possible to visit you,|
     v19                                |and I’ll recognize and discern not the message of those who’ve reached the point where their egos are|
     v19                                |inflated but rather their power; |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for the kingdom of God (i.e., God’s interaction with mankind) is not in a message but in power. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Which would you rather have? That I’d take a staff with me to correct you with when I go visit you, or|
     v21                                |that I’d visit you in a love-spirit and with soft-spoken gentleness?|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |News is going around that there’s actually fornication (i.e., sexual immorality) among you, the sort|

     v 2                                |of grieving and sorrow) in order that the one who’s committed this atrocity be removed from your midst.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To address this topic, although away physically-speaking but present spiritually-speaking, I have already|
     v 3                                |judged the one who’s doing this as if I was present |

 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You talking a big talk doesn’t make you look good—Don’t you know that a tiny pinch of yeast when placed|
     v 6                                |in a batch of dough will spread to the entire batch, causing every last bit of it to ferment? |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Scrub every bowl and utensil that came in contact with the old yeast thoroughly, so that you’d be a fresh|
     v 7                                |batch of dough the way that you really are: yeast-free dough. Add to this the fact that Christ was slaughtered|
     v 7                                |and offered as our Passover lamb sacrifice, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that we would not partake of the Passover meal with bread contaminated by yeast from the previous|
     v 8                                |batch nor contaminated by the yeast of unfathomably-wicked evil, but with the yeast-free bread of sincerity|
     v 8                                |and truth instead.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the previous letter I wrote that you shouldn’t associate with fornicators, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but I didn’t mean not to associate with any fornicator who’s a part of this corrupt society we live in,|
     v10                                |or with the greedy and rapacious or with idolaters; otherwise, if that were the case, you’d have to leave|
     v10                                |this corrupt society and shun it forever. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I wrote to you just now not to associate with someone if that someone who goes by the name “comrade”|
     v11                                |were to be a fornicator, or someone who’s greedy, or an idolater, or someone who cusses or uses abusive|
     v11                                |language, or a drunkard, or someone who’s rapacious—don’t share a meal with them either. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now about the issue of eating meat sacrificed to idols, every one of us has our own understanding of|
     v 1                                |how this ought to be handled. The understanding a person has on a given issue makes him rather full of|
     v 1                                |himself, but the love shown in the handling of said issue edifies. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If any given person thinks he’s reached the point where he’s acquired some level of understanding, he|
     v 2                                |has not yet understood the matter as it must be understood. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If someone loves God, this individual has been known and understood by Him.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now, about the consumption of food offered to idols: we know for a fact that the idols in the world|
     v 4                                |don’t amount to a hill of beans, and no person or thing is God except for One being only. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now, granted, there are those who claim there are gods, whether they be in the sky, in the atmosphere,|
     v 5                                |among the stars, in a spiritual world beyond that, or on the earth, so that there’re many gods and many|
     v 5                                |lords, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but from our point of view there’s one God the Father, out of Whom are all things, and we are returned|
     v 6                                |to Him and to the Lord Jesus Christ, through whom are all things, and we are through him.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That aside, we are not on the same level in every aspect of understanding. Up until now some people have|
     v 7                                |been in the habit of eating food sacrificed to idols, and since their consciences are weak (i.e., their|
     v 7                                |consciences prod them with pangs of guilt over matters they have a deficient understanding of, in this|
     v 7                                |case in regard to food sacrificed to idols), they violate their consciences. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Eating or not eating this food doesn’t get us anywhere with God: we’re neither worse off if we were to|
     v 8                                |not eat it nor are we better off if we were to eat it.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |See to it that the right you have to eat such food doesn’t somehow in and of itself become a stumbling|
     v 9                                |block (i.e., an influence for causing sin) for those who have a weak conscience. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, if someone with a weak conscience were to watch you, a person who has the correct understanding|
     v10                                |on this issue, sitting at the dinner table with food sacrificed to idols lying on the plate in front|
     v10                                |of you, wouldn’t his conscience, because it’s in a state of weakness, being built up in regard to the|
     v10                                |eating of foods sacrificed to idols (i.e., because of an incorrect understanding in regard to this issue|
     v10                                |of food sacrificed to idols, his conscience has been conditioned to respond with guilt when it ought|
     v10                                |not)? |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, he who’s weak—the comrade whom Christ died for—is being destroyed by your correct understanding.|
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the way that you sin against the comrades and beat on their weak consciences, you sin against Christ.|
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That’s why if food causes my comrade to stumble, there’s no way whatsoever that I’ll ever eat sacrificial|
     v13                                |meat again, so that I won’t be a stumbling block to my brother.|
