  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Chapter 9  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Am I not a freeman? Am I not an apostle (i.e., have I not been sent by God to pioneer the spread of Christianity)?|
     v 1                                |Have I not seen our Lord Jesus with my own eyes? Are you not my accomplishment in the Lord? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If I’m not an apostle sent to root others in Christianity, at least I’m an apostle sent to root you;|
     v 2                                |in fact, you’re my certificate of authenticity of my having been sent by the Lord. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My rebuttal to those examining me for the purpose of judging and condemning me is the same.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Do we not have the right to be hosted in such a way that we eat and drink for free? |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Do we not have the right to have a fellow-comrade-wife accompany us as she follows our lead on our journeys|
     v 5                                |and have her hosted as well, as all the other apostles of the Lord and Peter do?— |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or is it just Barnabas and I who don’t have the right to not have to work to support ourselves? |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When did any soldier ever serve in the army and have to pay for his own rations? Who plants a vineyard|
     v 7                                |and doesn’t feed off what it produces? Or who cares for a ewe and doesn’t feed off the sheep’s milk?|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m not talking from a human perspective, or talking about concepts that the Law does not also talk about.|
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is, in the Law of Moses it’s written, “Don’t put a muzzle on an oxen while it’s|
     v 9                                |threshing wheat.” You don’t think God cares about the welfare of the oxen when it’s threshing, do you?|
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or is it that the Law’s addressing this topic for our benefit? Furthermore, it’s written in the Law for|
     v10                                |our benefit that the sower ought to sow and the thresher to thresh with the hope of getting a percentage|
     v10                                |of the harvest. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we sowed into you the Holy Spirit-related things which are the backbone of your spiritual lives, is|
     v11                                |it a big deal if we reap the physical things we need to live by from you? |
   N V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If others have the right of taking a percentage from you, don’t we all the more so?|
 +P  V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No, we’re not asserting this right; instead we put up with all kinds of things so that nothing would|
     v12                                |hinder the Gospel, the good-news message of Christ. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t you know that they who work the sacred duties in the temple feed on the sacrifices offered at the|
     v13                                |temple; that they who attend to the altar divide the spoils of the altar among themselves? |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the same way the Lord planned for and commanded those who proclaim the Gospel to make their living|
     v14                                |from the Gospel. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I have not used any of these mandates. I didn’t write about these things to make them happen to me; in|
     v15                                |fact, I’d rather die than have someone invalidate the proud assertions which I openly pride myself in.|
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Should I proclaim the Gospel, it’s not my place to make proud assertions, you see: by necessity they’re|
     v16                                |imposed on me. I’ll be in deep trouble, you see, should I not proclaim the Gospel. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If I put this into practice voluntarily, you see, I’ll earn my pay. If I do this voluntarily, I’ve reached|
     v17                                |the point where I can be entrusted with a managerial position. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So what’s my pay rate? I’m not getting paid a penny so that I can present the Gospel free of charge with|
     v18                                |a view towards me not exercising my right to receive financial support as one who proclaims the Gospel.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Being a freeman, freed from all things, in all things I made myself a slave, so that I’d win over the|
     v19                                |many. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I became a Jew to the Jews so that I would win over Jews: to those who live under the Law of Moses, I|
     v20                                |let myself be under the Law (though as far as my own personal life is concerned, I’m not under the Law),|
     v20                                |so that I would win over those under the Law. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I became lawless (i.e., not living under the Law of Moses or under any God-based set of rules for that|

     v21                                |Christ) in order to win over the lawless. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I became powerless to control my own circumstances to those who are powerless over their circumstances|

     v22                                |calamity, spiritual, moral, and otherwise) some. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But everything I do, I do for the sake of the proclamation of the Gospel so I’d become a workman who|
     v23                                |specializes in it.|

     v26                                |of air. |

     v27                                |it roughly and wearing it down; I subdue it and make it my slave, lest I, having proclaimed the Gospel|
     v27                                |to others, should somehow or someway fail to live up to the standard it sets.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR1 Chapter 12  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Concerning spirituals (things which are of nature related to the Holy Spirit: i.e., spiritual gifts,|
     v 1                                |ministries, and extraordinary manifestations of the Holy Spirit), comrades, I don’t want you to fail|
     v 1                                |to understand this. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You know for a fact that when you were pagans in close contact with the mute and dumb idols, as long|
     v 2                                |as you kept on being led by the evil spirits those idols attracted, you were being led astray. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is why I’m making you understand that no one while speaking by means of the Spirit of God says “Jesus|
     v 3                                |is accursed,” and no one when speaking by the influence of a spirit can say “Jesus is Lord” except if|
     v 3                                |the influence is by the Holy Spirit.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now there’s a variety of gifts, gifts which are freely given by God as an act of grace and not as something|
     v 4                                |which have been earned by the recipient, but the same Spirit. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And there are a variety of ministries, but the same Spirit still. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And there are a variety of effects produced by the Holy Spirit, but the same God Who works every little|
     v 6                                |piece of everything. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To each is given the manifestation of the Spirit for the common good. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard, through the Spirit is given to one person the word of wisdom, but on the other hand to|
     v 8                                |another person the word of knowledge according to the same Spirit, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to another special faith by the same Spirit, but to another gifts of healings by the same Spirit, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but to another the working of miracles, but to another prophecy, but to another the discerning of spirits,|
     v10                                |but to another a different kind of tongue, to another the interpretation of tongues. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The one-in-the-same Spirit works all of these gifts, ministries, and effects, divvying them up and parceling|
     v11                                |them out to each individual just the way He wants.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, just as the body is a single unit and has many parts, and all the parts, even though there’s|
     v12                                |many of them, comprise one body, it’s the same way with Christ. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, every one of us was inducted into one body by one Spirit, whether a given person was Jewish,|
     v13                                |was a Westerner, whether a slave or freeman—all of us have been made to drink of the water of life from|
     v13                                |one Spirit; |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for the body does not consist of one part only but of many parts. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If the foot were to say, “I’m not a hand—I’m not one of the parts the body has,” then because of this|
     v15                                |claim it’s not a constituent body part? |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And if the ear were to say, “I’m not an eye, I’m not part of the body,” because of saying this, it’s|
     v16                                |not part of the body? |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If the entire body was just one giant eye, how would you hear? If the entire body was just one giant|
     v17                                |ear, how could you smell anything?|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So as it turns out God put every one of the parts into position just the way He wanted. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If every little piece was one type of part only, where would that leave the body? |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It turns out that while there’re many parts indeed, there’s but one body. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The eye can’t get away with telling the hand “I don’t need you”; furthermore, the head can’t tell the|
     v21                                |feet “I don’t need you” either. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No—the parts of the body which seem to be weaker are more necessary than they appear to be. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We assign a greater value to the parts of the body we deem to be of little value, and we put a greater|
     v23                                |amount of clothing over our private parts to ensure that they’re well-hidden, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but the valuable parts have no need of that. No—God composed—He blended together and mixed—the body by|
     v24                                |having given more value to those parts lacking it |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so there wouldn’t be division in the body, but that the members would care for each other treating each|
     v25                                |other the same way. |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a single member happens to suffer, all the members suffer along with it. If a single member is glorified,|
     v26                                |all the members are glorified along with it.|
 +   V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now you all are Christ’s body, and you as the individual members populate the various body parts. |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God has indeed placed in the church first apostles (i.e., missionaries sent out to pioneer new Christian|
     v28                                |works), second prophets, third teachers, those who perform miracles, gifts of healings, those who help|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pursue love and have a burning desire for the spirituals (i.e., spiritual gifts and manifestations of|

     v 5                                |what was spoken in tongues, so that the church would receive edification.|

     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Nevertheless the inanimate objects which are designed to produce specific, coherent sound patterns, whether|
     v 7                                |we’re talking about a flute or a harp—if one of them were to not put out distinct musical notes, how|
     v 7                                |will the flute-playing or harp-playing be comprehensible? |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, if a bugle were to play an indistinguishable tune, who would get into position for battle?|

     v 9                                |spoken be comprehensible? The fact of the matter is that you would just be wasting your breath. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Concerning the matter of taking up a collection for the poor and sending it to God’s people in Jerusalem,|
     v 1                                |do the same thing that I commanded the churches in Galatia to do: |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let each of you in private stash away a bit of your money every Sunday—whatever you can afford—so that|
     v 2                                |when I come, there won’t be any collection-taking going on then. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When I make it over to your place, whomever you happen to decide upon to write letters of recommendation|
     v 3                                |for, I’ll dispatch as couriers to take your gift to Jerusalem. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If there happens to be an issue of respect, they’ll come with me when I depart.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ll come your way when I pass through Macedonia; I’ll be passing through Macedonia, you see. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Perhaps I’ll stay with you a while or even spend the winter, so that you’ll send me on my way refreshed|
     v 6                                |and prepared for the journey wherever I happen to go; |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, at the moment I don’t want to just stop by for a short visit while passing through the area;|
     v 7                                |you see, I hope to stay a while with you, if the Lord permits. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ll stay in Ephesus until Pentecost (i.e., until late May to early June). |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, a great door (i.e., a tremendous opportunity) has been opened for me and it looks promising,|
     v 9                                |but I’ll have to face many adversaries.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If Timothy happens to show up, see to it that he doesn’t get to where he’s intimidated by you; he’s doing|
     v10                                |the Lord’s work like I’m doing, you see, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so don’t let anyone treat him disrespectfully or despise him. Send him forth to his next destination|
     v11                                |in peace (i.e., take care of him, treat him well, and send him out prepared for the journey), so that|
     v11                                |he manages to come to me, for I expect him with the group of comrades who’ll be coming.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Concerning Comrade Apollos…I’ve encouraged him an awful lot to pay you a visit, doing so by travelling|
     v12                                |with the comrades who’ll be coming, and it wasn’t his desire altogether to go at this time, but he’ll|
     v12                                |go in good time.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Stay focused, take a firm stand in the faith, man up, seize control and hold on tightly. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let everything you do manifest itself in love.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I appeal to you, comrades…you know first-hand Stephanas’s household, since they’re the crème de la crème|
     v15                                |of the converts of Achaia and have been put in positions of deacons for God’s people, the saints…|
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I appeal to you that you too would submit to such fine individuals as these and to all the fellow-workers|
     v16                                |and laborers. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m so glad that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus showed up, that these fellows filled in the pieces|
     v17                                |that you’re missing: |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |they gave rest to my spirit and to yours, so recognize the character and contribution of men such as|
     v18                                |these.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The churches in the Roman province of Asia send their greetings to you. Aquila and Priscilla send many|
     v19                                |greetings to you in the Lord and are joined in their greetings with the group of Christians who meet|
     v19                                |in their house. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All the comrades greet you. Give each other a hearty handshake and an affectionate hug—holy ones—for|
     v20                                |me.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The greeting written here is in my own handwriting, that of Paul’s. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If anyone doesn’t like the Lord a lot, let him be accursed. Maranatha (Do come Lord).|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you all. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May my love be with all of you in Christ Jesus.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by God’s will, and his fellow comrade Timothy—|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the church of God that is in Corinth, joined by the saints (i.e., God’s people) who are all over Achaia:|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Give praise to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Originator of all sorts of compassion|
     v 3                                |and of advice, encouragement, and consolation, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which consoles, etc. us in all of our distresses, resulting in our ability to console those in all kinds|
     v 4                                |of distresses with the same consolation with which we’re being consoled by God. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just as Christ’s sufferings proliferate to us, in the same way through Christ the consolation we receive|
     v 5                                |proliferates as well. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Whether we’re being pressured, it’s for the sake of your consolation and salvation (i.e., your being|
     v 6                                |rescued from spiritual, moral, mental, and physical calamity); whether we’re being consoled, it’s for|
     v 6                                |the sake of your consolation, a consolation which is accomplished by enduring the same sufferings which|
     v 6                                |we too suffer. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the hope which we have for you—our hope is firm, fixed in the observation that as you are joint participants|
     v 7                                |of the sufferings which we suffer, in the same way you are joint participants of the consolation as well.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard, we don’t want you to be left in the dark, comrades, about the extreme difficulties we|
     v 8                                |experienced in the Roman province of Asia, that we were overloaded and overwhelmed to the point that|
     v 8                                |we lost the will to live. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Anyways, deep inside ourselves we concluded that we were doomed to die, so we reached the point where|
     v 9                                |we couldn’t be convinced that our own abilities would save us, but were convinced that the God who raises|
     v 9                                |the dead would do so instead: |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |He Who rescued us from a narrow brush with death—and rescues us continuously—we set our hope in Him that|
     v10                                |He’ll rescue us yet again, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |while you too were joining in lending a helping hand by the prayers that you prayed for us, so that the|
     v11                                |outcome of the stances, disposition, and full attention of many people is that the mercy and kindness|
     v11                                |shown to us would be thanked by many on our behalf.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, our proud talk and bold claims are on par with the solemn declaration of our conscience, since|
     v12                                |the lifestyle we led in the world (i.e., among those who aren’t believers) was by God’s simplicity and|
     v12                                |sincerity, not by the wisdom of flesh (i.e., by the cunning shrewdness of our own ability apart from|
     v12                                |God tainted by the carnal nature) but by God’s grace instead—and that lifestyle was all the more so with|
     v12                                |you. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact we’re writing to you nothing other than what you’re reading to the congregation or what you’re|
     v13                                |coming to understand, but I hope that you continue to gain an exact understanding until it’s all said|
     v13                                |and done, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |just as you also gained an understanding of us, at least partially, that we are the reason for your proud|
     v14                                |talk and bold claims just as you too will be ours in the Day of the Lord Jesus (i.e., when he’s revealed|
     v14                                |in the fullness of his might).|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We formed a long-term desire for this, for what we’ve reached the point where we’re convinced is the|
     v15                                |thing that we want to do more than anything else, namely to go visit you, so that you would get a second|
     v15                                |grace (i.e., a second impartation of our face-to-face ministry), |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to continue on our journey through your city to Macedonia, to resume the journey going from Macedonia|
     v16                                |back to your city again, and to be sent forth by you (i.e., depart fully rested, provisioned, and in|
     v16                                |good spirits—all on account of the your generosity and hospitality) to the Jews in Judea.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, was this plan treated with a nonchalant thought-process? Or what I’m planning, I’m planning|
     v17                                |according to flesh (i.e., from my own self apart from God, according to my own needs, and somewhat tainted|
     v17                                |to feed my carnal appetite), so that it would be “the yes-yes and the no-no” with me (i.e., I’d vacillate|
     v17                                |or renege on what I planned or promised to do)? |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But—by God—trust me that the statements we made to you aren’t “the yes-yes and the no-no.” |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, God’s son Jesus Christ, who through us has been preached among you—through me, Siloam,|
     v19                                |and Timothy—hasn’t wound up being “the yes-yes and the no-no,” but rather has wound up being “yes” in|
     v19                                |him. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For as many promises as there are from God, in him they are all “yes” (i.e., no vacillating or reneging|
     v20                                |on them), and in light of this through him is also the Amen (i.e., the acknowledgement of the finality|
     v20                                |of a matter; the familiar profession to God of “Let it be so”) to God with glory through us. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |God’s establishing us together with you in Christ and anointed us. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |He also stamped us with His seal of approval and gave us the down payment of the Spirit in our hearts.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I swear to God—cross my heart and hope to die—that it was to spare you that I no longer went to Corinth—|
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not that we act in a domineering manner towards you of the Faith—no—we work together as helpers of your|
     v24                                |grace: for you have stood by faith.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Getting to the point, I made up my mind that I wouldn’t visit you again while laden with the pains of|
     v 1                                |sorrow. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, if I’m making you feel sorry, who in particular will cheer me up apart from the one I made feel|
     v 2                                |sorry? |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The very thing I wrote, I wrote so that I wouldn’t come for a visit and wind up being made sorry by the|
     v 3                                |ones I ought to rejoice over, as my nearness to you all has convinced me that my joy is derived from|
     v 3                                |you all. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, what I wrote to you through many tears came out of a great deal of distress and heart-felt anguish,|
     v 4                                |not so that it would cause you sorrow, but so that you’d understand the abundant love which I have for|
     v 4                                |you.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a certain person has caused sorrow, he hasn’t caused me sorrow (actually no, he has partially), so|
     v 5                                |I won’t dump any more of this on you all. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The very punishment inflicted by the many is enough for such a person, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that on the flip-side, you should be all the more kind and merciful to him and comfort and encourage|
     v 7                                |him, so that such a person not somehow be deluged with even more sorrow. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this I advise you to broadcast love to him. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, another reason I wrote is so that I could discern if you live up to my standards, that is if|
     v 9                                |you obey everything you’re told. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if you forgive somebody of something, so do I; you see, if in addition to you I forgave somebody|
     v10                                |of something, what I’ve forgiven (assuming there’s something I’m forgiving), I did so through you under|
     v10                                |the scrutiny of Christ, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that we won’t be swindled by Satan: we are not ignorant of his intentions, you see.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now that I’ve arrived at Troas for the purpose of spreading the Gospel of Christ (i.e., the good news|
     v12                                |about Christ), a door has been opened to me in the Lord (i.e., in regard to the things of the Lord, a|
     v12                                |tremendous opportunity has presented itself to me), |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I was uncomfortable in my spirit not finding my fellow-comrade Titus, so instead I excused myself, said|
     v13                                |goodbye to them, and left for Macedonia.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But thank-you God, Who always makes us roadies on Christ’s victory tour, and Who’s propagating the fragrance|
     v14                                |of his knowledge through us in all regions, |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since in God we are a pleasant aroma (like the incense they burned in the Old Testament, or the pleasing|
     v15                                |smell of a burnt offering) of Christ among those being saved (i.e., those being rescued from calamity)|
     v15                                |and among those perishing; |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |we who on the one hand are a whiff of going from death to even more death, and on the other hand are|
     v16                                |a whiff of going from life to even more life—and that’s not good enough for some people? |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we’re not like so many other preachers who hustle the word of God—no—we preach the Gospel like|
     v17                                |it’s coming from someone who’s sincere through-and-through—no—we speak the word of God in Christ like|
     v17                                |it’s coming directly from God while we stand before God.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Are my comrades and I starting over again in doing self-promotion to bolster your opinion of us? Put|
     v 1                                |another way, we’re not in need of letters of recommendation to be sent to you or to be received from|
     v 1                                |you, like some people do, are we? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You are our letter of recommendation, written in our hearts, understood and read by all people. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It’s plain for all to see that you are a letter of Christ transcribed and delivered by us; not written|
     v 3                                |with ink, but with the Spirit of the Living God; not written in stone but written in a flesh-heart.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re convinced that we have such a thing through Christ with God— |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that we’re up-to-par in and of ourselves to where we figure that something in particular which is|
     v 5                                |good was self-generated, but rather that our adequacy comes out of God, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Who also made us up-to-par ministers of a new covenant, not of the letter (i.e., the literal, exacting|
     v 6                                |listing of rules, compliance with those rules, and consequences for breaking them) but of the Spirit:|
     v 6                                |for the letter kills, but the Spirit causes things to spring into life.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now if the administering of death, which was packaged in letters etched in stone, occurred in glory to|
     v 7                                |the point that it wasn’t possible for the run-of-the-mill Israelite to gaze at Moses’s face because of|
     v 7                                |the glory of his face—a glory that was deteriorating no less— |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |how much more will the administering of the Spirit be accompanied by glory? |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, if there was glory in the administering of condemnation, how much more does the administering|
     v 9                                |of righteousness exceed it in glory? |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And furthermore, that which has been made glorious hasn’t been made glorious relative to the glory which|
     v10                                |surpasses it. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, if the glory which has been nullified has been nullified by glory, the glory which remains does|
     v11                                |so all the more in glory.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So having such hope, in our outspokenness and boldness we conceal nothing, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |unlike Moses who placed a veil over his face so that the run-of-the-mill Israelites couldn’t gaze at|
     v13                                |the vestige of the glory that was deteriorating— |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not a chance—their minds were dead-set against it. In fact to this very day the same veil remains uncovered|
     v14                                |at the reading of the Old Testament, since it’s done away with in Christ. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No—to this day whenever the Old Testament happens to be read aloud a veil lies over their heart, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but, if they were to turn to the Lord, the moment they do so, the veil gets taken off.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now the Lord is in lockstep with the Spirit, and there’s freedom where the Spirit of the Lord is. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While gazing at the glory of the Lord with an uncovered face as though we’re looking intently in a mirror,|
     v18                                |we all are transformed into the same image going from one gaze of glory to another gaze of even more|
     v18                                |glory, just as we go from one gaze of the Spirit of the Lord to another gaze of even more of the Spirit.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 4  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |On account of this, that is of having this administering of righteousness, to the degree that we’ve been|
     v 1                                |shown mercy, we don’t lose heart— |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |on the contrary, we quit for good doing those things that we’re ashamed of that we keep hidden, not going|
     v 2                                |here and there playing games with people, nor putting a spin on the word of God, rather by means of the|
     v 2                                |propagation of the truth we leave a good impression deep inside of everyone else while under God’s scrutiny.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But even if our Gospel, our Good News Message, is veiled, it’s veiled among those who are perishing,|
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |among whom the god of this age (i.e., this current era of mankind’s history) blinded the minds of those|
     v 4                                |who refuse to believe to where they don’t see the light of the Gospel of the glory of Christ, who is|
     v 4                                |a spitting image of God. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we don’t preach that we ourselves are your superiors but rather that Jesus Christ is Lord, and|
     v 5                                |that we ourselves are your humble servants on account of Jesus, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since the God Who said, “Light shall shine out of darkness,” is the One Who shined in our hearts with|
     v 6                                |the light of the knowledge and understanding of the glory of God by means of the direct attention of|
     v 6                                |Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We have this treasure in clay storage vessels (i.e., physical bodies) so that the over-and-above power|
     v 7                                |would be of God and not from ourselves. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re pressured from every direction and in trouble, but no—we’re not at the end of our rope; confused|
     v 8                                |as to what to do—but not totally confused; |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |persecuted but not abandoned; knocked off our feet but not destroyed; |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |always carrying around in our body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus would also be manifested|
     v10                                |in our body. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we the living are forever being forced into a position where death has control over us because|
     v11                                |of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus would also be manifested in our mortal body.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, the death I just described is at work in us, but the life I likewise described is at work in|
     v12                                |you. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Having a spirit of (i.e., a prevailing attitude of) faith that’s the same as what’s written in the Old|
     v13                                |Testament, “I believed, and in light of it all I spoke,” we too believe, and in light of it all we too|
     v13                                |speak, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing for a fact that He who raised the Lord Jesus will also raise us together with Jesus and together|
     v14                                |with him cast us in a favorable light in God’s estimation. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, all these things are for your sake, so that the grace bestowed on us, having proliferated through|
     v15                                |the thanksgiving of the many, would abound to God’s glory.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this we’re not losing heart; on the contrary, even though our outer-person is deteriorating,|
     v16                                |yet our inner-person is being renewed day-in, day-out. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, the light weight of our affliction is incomparable to the heavy weight of glory at work|
     v17                                |in us, |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |while we’re not looking at the things which are seen but the things that are not seen: for the things|
     v18                                |which are seen are transient, but the things which are not seen are eternal.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||
    [ COR2 Chapter 4 has no footnotes ]

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COR2 Chapter 5  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, we know for certain that if our Earth-suit were to be demolished, we have a building from God—an|
     v 1                                |eternal building, one that’s not of human construction—way up in the sky. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In connection to this we do groan, longing to put on (i.e., as though putting on a piece of clothing)|
     v 2                                |our home—our cozy cottage—which comes from heaven. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we really have put on our eternal building, we won’t be caught naked. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, we whose present form of existence is with the Earth-suit do groan, being encumbered, the|
     v 4                                |crux of which is that we don’t want to be stripped of our garments but to be clothed instead, so that|
     v 4                                |the death we carry about would be thoroughly dowsed by the life. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now He Who did the necessary work in us to make this very thing happen to us is God, the One Who gave|
     v 5                                |us the down payment of the Spirit.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So keep your chin up—always—and know for certain that making yourselves at home in the body will leave|
     v 6                                |you far from home with the Lord |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |(we go about our lives by faith and not by sight, you see), |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but with our chins held high and thinking positively, we’d rather be far from home in regard to the body|
     v 8                                |but make ourselves at home with the Lord. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And so whether at home or away from home, we aspire to be pleasing to him: |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the fact of the matter is that every one of us must appear before the Judge, Christ the Judge, so that|
     v10                                |each individual’s deeds, deeds which were committed by the body, whether they were good or bad—all of|
     v10                                |them—would be brought before the Judge to be judged by him.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now that we’ve acquired a firm understanding of the fear of the Lord, we convince other people to do|
     v11                                |the same. We’ve been made manifest to God (i.e., we’ve presented ourselves before God), and I hope to|
     v11                                |reach the point where we’ve been made manifest to your consciences as well— |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that we’re trying to promote ourselves again, but are giving you the chance to talk proudly about|
     v12                                |us instead, so that you would have something good to say to those who take pride in and talk big about|
     v12                                |peoples’ behavior on the surface, or the masks people present to others, and not what’s in the heart.|
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that if it’s the case that I’ve lost my mind, I’ve lost my mind for God; if|
     v13                                |it’s the case that I’m sane, I’m sane for you. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The love of Christ has a tight grip on us, you see, and has determined that this is the case: that one|
     v14                                |person died in everyone’s place (therefore everyone died), |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and he died in everyone’s place so that the living would no longer live for themselves but that they|
     v15                                |would instead live for him who died and was raised in their place.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |An outcome of all this is that, from now on, there’s nobody we form a perception of according to the|
     v16                                |flesh (i.e., according to a person’s physical body and outward appearance; his limited ability in and|
     v16                                |of himself), even if we had come to know and understand Christ according to the flesh—but, no, we no|
     v16                                |longer know and understand him according to the flesh.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |An outcome of all this is that if someone is in Christ (melded with him: in him, with him, and living|
     v17                                |life by means of him), he’s a new type of species, a new kind of creature, a new creation: the old has|
     v17                                |come and gone and—get this—the new has come into being. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now all these new things are from God, Who by Christ reconciled us with Himself and gave us the Reconciliation|
     v18                                |Ministry, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |that is that God was in Christ reconciling the world (i.e., those who don’t know and live for God) to|
     v19                                |Himself, not holding all the times they crossed over the line in doing wrong as strikes against them,|
     v19                                |and assigning to us the task of keeping and spreading the message of reconciliation. |

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I, Paul, through the gentle restraint and kindness of Christ, who, when I was here on Earth face-to-face|

     v 2                                |flesh (i.e. of our own ability apart from God; as though God doesn’t work through us). |

     v 3                                |we don’t wage war according to the flesh: |

     v 4                                |it’s quite capable in God of leveling heavily-fortified defenses—leveling schemes, machinations, detailed|
     v 4                                |plans, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and every erected fortification or entrenched high-ground which opposes the knowledge and understanding|
     v 5                                |of God, and capturing every thought and making it a prisoner of the obedience of Christ, |

     v 7                                |the same way as he. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So now, if I venture to say something even more cocky about our authority (an authority which the Lord|

     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |No, we don’t speak proudly about things outside our sphere, namely about the toils of others, but we’re|

     v12                                |the conclusion that they’re also like us. |

     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And it’s not surprising: Satan himself disguises himself as an angel of light. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So there’s not a huge difference if his servants the false apostles also disguise themselves as servants|
     v15                                |of righteousness. The way it ends for these false apostles will be in step with their deeds.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Moving on to another topic. Nobody should take me for a fool, but should it be otherwise, accept me even|
     v16                                |as a fool, so that even as a fool I have some little thing or two to say about my tremendous accomplishments.|
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What I’m about to say isn’t in line with how the Lord speaks, but are words you’d expect to come out|
     v17                                |of one in the throes of folly—the essence of the boasting you’re about to hear.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Since many are talking up great things they’ve done according to flesh (i.e., from their own ability|
     v18                                |apart from God; taking credit for it personally and not giving God the credit), I’ll talk up my tremendous|
     v18                                |accomplishments too. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is, you’re more than happy to tolerate what the fools spout off, treating them|
     v19                                |like they’re sensible and wise. |

     v20                                |the head. |

     v21                                |might dare speak proudly about.|
 +P  V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m talking foolishly, but I’ll dare speak anyways. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Are they native-Hebrew speakers and live by the ancient Jewish culture?—So do I. Are they Israelites?—So|
     v22                                |am I. Are they father-to-son direct descendants and heirs of Abraham?—So am I. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Are they Christ’s servants (I’m talking like a mad man)?—I’ll up them one: as far as hard labor goes,|
     v23                                |I’ve done more. I’ve spent more time in prison. I’ve received more beatings. I’ve had more near-death|
     v23                                |experiences: |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ve received the thirty-nine lash punishment by the Jews five times; |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ve been beaten with staffs three times; I was stoned to death once; I was shipwrecked three times;|
     v25                                |I spent twenty-four straight hours floundering out in the ocean. |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ve been on the road many a time walking great distances; I’ve been in danger while travelling by river;|
     v26                                |in danger from robbers; in danger by my fellow countrymen; in danger by those in faraway countries; in|
     v26                                |danger in the city; in danger in the countryside; in danger on the high seas; in danger from phony comrades;|
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I worked hard, long hours and did heavy manual labor; had many a sleepless night; went long stretches|
     v27                                |with nothing to eat or nothing to drink; fasted many times; was cold because I had nothing to wear— |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Besides those external pressures, there is the pressure on the inside of me due to the day-to-day responsibility|
     v28                                |for all the churches, worrying over them. |
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Who’s weak (i.e., sickly, frail, or simply unable to muster the strength to face life’s challenges),|
     v29                                |and I’m not weak along with them? Who stumbles (i.e. falls away from the walk of faith; falls into sin;|
     v29                                |is overcome by temptation; stops following God), and I’m not raving over it?|
 +   V30              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If there has to be proud talk about tremendous things which have taken place, I’ll speak proudly about|

     v30                                |to overcome the difficulties I faced). |
     V31              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The God and Father of our Lord Jesus—He Who’s blessed forevermore—knows for a fact that I’m not lying—|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From the Apostle (i.e., missionary; pioneer of new churches; worker of miracles) Paul, who’s not an apostle|
     v 1                                |created from human agency nor an apostle who exists through human agency but through Jesus Christ and|
     v 1                                |God, the Father Who raised him from the dead, |
   N V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and from those who are together with me—not just physically but are joint participants in my endeavors—namely|
     v 2                                |all of the comrades:|
 +P  V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the churches of Galatia:|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who gave his own self for our sins, and gave himself so he could yank us out of this evil day-and-age|
     v 4                                |we live in, according to the will of our God and Father: |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to Him be the glory forever and ever (and let us pause a moment for that to sink in):|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m astounded that you’re setting aside and replacing the Gospel (i.e., the good-news message we preach)|
     v 6                                |which came from the One Who called us (i.e., summoned us to believe) by the grace of Christ in exchange|
     v 6                                |for another so-called gospel— |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not that there’s another gospel to be had—but I’m astounded at how this could possibly happen except|
     v 7                                |for the fact that there are certain individuals among you who are trouble-makers, wanting to distort|
     v 7                                |the Gospel, the message of what Christ did. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Never mind that for a moment: if even we or an angel who came down from heaven were to evangelize to|
     v 8                                |you something different than what we evangelized to you, let him be accursed. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I said it before and I’ll say it again: if someone evangelizes you with something different than what|
     v 9                                |you received and took to heart already, let him be accursed.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, am I trying to win people or God over to my side now? Or am I just trying to please people?|
     v10                                |If I was still going about pleasing people, I wouldn’t be a slave of Christ.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just to let you know, comrades, the Gospel which was evangelized by me: it’s not a man-made contrivance,|
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor were we taught it by anyone, but rather we were taught it through a Jesus Christ-revelation.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, you heard about the way I used to live back then when I lived as a strict Jew, that I was caught|
     v13                                |up in persecuting God’s church to an inordinate degree and in wreaking havoc on it, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and I was getting deeper and deeper into the stricter practices of Judaism, well beyond many of my peers,|
     v14                                |as I had become even more fanatical about all the man-made rules and regulations that were passed down|
     v14                                |to me from my ancestors. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But when God, Who set me apart from the time I was in my mother’s womb and called me through His grace,|
     v15                                |was pleased |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to reveal His son in me so I’d evangelize him to the Gentiles, I didn’t drop everything I was doing and|
     v16                                |see what the experts had to say about it, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor did I go down to Jerusalem to secure the approval of the founding apostles, who are my superiors|
     v17                                |by default, but went over to Arabia instead and returned to Damascus.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then after three years I went down to Jerusalem to visit Peter and stayed with him for fifteen days.|
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But I didn’t see the other apostles except for the Lord’s brother James. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |(What I’m writing here for you—look—I swear to God I’m not lying.) |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then I went to the districts of Syria and Cilicia. |

     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and they glorified the God who is with me.|

     v 9                                |honchos) were in total agreement with us giving their unequivocal endorsement and full support to me|

     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They only asked that we remember the poor, the very same thing I too had been eager to get done.|

     v12                                |of meals with the Gentiles, but when they arrived, he withdrew from the Gentiles and kept himself at|
     v12                                |a distance from them, fearing those from the circumcision (i.e., those who believe that one must obey|
     v12                                |the Law of Moses and adopt Jewish rules and restrictions in order to be accepted by God; those who say|
     v12                                |that believing in Christ but not following the Law is not acceptable to God). |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The other Jews joined him in his hypocrisy, so that even Barnabas was caught up in the hypocrisy…|
 + N V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |—Not a chance.|
 +P  V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When I saw that he was disingenuous about the truth of the Gospel, I told Peter in front of everybody,|
     v14                                |“If you being a Jew live as a Gentile and not as a Jew, how can you get away with requiring that the|
     v14                                |Gentiles be Jewish?”|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |”We ourselves are Jews by nature and not sinners from far-away, Gentile nations, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having reached the point where we know for certain that a person isn’t justified (i.e., God examining|
     v16                                |a person’s righteousness like a judge would and declaring them to be righteous) as a result of works|
     v16                                |of law (i.e., obeying the commandments of the Law of Moses, or following the do’s and don’ts of any godly|
     v16                                |list of rules for that matter) if it happens to not be through Christ Jesus-faith. We believed in Christ|
     v16                                |Jesus so that we would be justified as a result of Christ-faith and not as a result of works of law,|
     v16                                |since all flesh (i.e., any human endeavor and all human effort apart from God) won’t be justified as|
     v16                                |a result of works of law. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if in the process of seeking justification in Christ, it’s been determined that even we are sinners,|
     v17                                |you can’t seriously believe that Christ has been delegated the responsibility of caring for and promoting|
     v17                                |sin?—No way.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |”Furthermore, if I rebuild the things that I demolished, I demonstrate conclusively that I’m a transgressor.|
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, because of law I died to law (i.e., because of the failure in trying to live up to the requirements|
     v19                                |of the Law of Moses—which can be said of any set of rules and not just the Law of Moses—and thereby earning|
     v19                                |righteousness, I ceased all attempts and completely severed myself from earning righteousness through|
     v19                                |the Law), so that I would live to God. I’ve been crucified in unison, in joint participation, with Christ;|
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. What I now live in flesh (i.e., in my physical body, with my|
     v20                                |human ability, and in contention with my carnal nature), I live by faith for the son of God who loved|
     v20                                |me and gave himself for me. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m not nullifying the grace of God: if one is justified through law, Christ really did die for nothing.“|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Oh, brainless, short-sighted Galatians, who cast an evil spell over you, you whom eye-witness accounts|
     v 1                                |of Jesus Christ were previously written for, accounts describing his being crucified? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The only thing I want to ascertain from you is this: Did you receive the Spirit from the works of law|
     v 2                                |(i.e., following the do’s and don’ts of the Law of Moses, or any other list of rules for that matter)|
     v 2                                |or from hearing a particular message from the vantage point of faith?|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You’re brainless this way. Having begun in spirit (i.e., living a spiritual life; a life where your regenerate,|

     v 6                                |through love.|

     v 8                                |who summoned you to believe in Him). |

     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m satisfied in the Lord that you won’t arrive at any other conclusion than the truth, but the troublemaker|
     v10                                |who’s causing you problems will suffer the consequences, whoever he happens to be. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But in my case, comrades—if I happened to still be preaching circumcision (i.e., preaching that one must|
     v11                                |obey the Law of Moses and seek righteousness by following it), why would I continue to be persecuted?|
     v11                                |Has the point of contention and the offensiveness of the cross really been abolished? |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Would that those who are agitating you go on to be castrated!|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that you were called (i.e., became believers) to be at a place of freedom,|
     v13                                |comrades: just don’t turn the freedom in Christ into a pretext for flesh (i.e., a pretext to act apart|
     v13                                |from God or to indulge your carnal nature), but serve one another as slaves through the love God has|
     v13                                |put in us instead. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the entirety of what the Law teaches is summarized in one sentence: “You shall love your neighbor|
     v14                                |as yourself”; |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but if you’re vicious towards one another, aggressive, and take advantage of each other or have total|
     v15                                |disregard for each other, be careful that you don’t rip each other to shreds.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ll say this: conduct your lives in a spiritual manner (i.e., by your spirit in communion with the Holy|
     v16                                |Spirit) and you won’t carry out the desires of the flesh (i.e., the carnal nature)—not a chance. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The flesh, you see, has intense, sexual-like desires contrary to the Spirit, and the Spirit is contrary|
     v17                                |to the flesh: in fact these two are pitted against each other, so that that which you happen to be wanting,|
     v17                                |those are the things you won’t be doing. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if you are led in a spiritual manner, you are not under law (i.e., you’re not subordinated to a set|

     v19                                |behavior of any sort; lewd, crude, crass, foul-mouthed, disgusting untidiness, abject neglect of personal|

     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |idolatry (i.e., replacing God with something else; looking for something else to do what God promised|

     v20                                |rivalry driven by jealousy; envy; competing in an unhealthy way to outdo someone else); wrath (i.e.,|
     v20                                |a hot, out-of-control temper; unwarranted outbursts of anger); selfish ambition, playing politics, or|
     v20                                |manipulating those around you for your own selfish ends; seditions (i.e., dissensions, unresolved disputes);|
     v20                                |factions (i.e., the formation and perpetuation of groups hostile to each other); |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |jealousy (i.e., envious of someone else who does well; hatred of someone simply because they’re doing|

     v21                                |partying; hell-raising for the fun of it); etc., etc.—I told you before and I’ll tell you again: those|
