  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS2 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS2 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From Paul, Silas, and Timothy:|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the church in Thessalonica in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace to you and peace from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We ought to thank God for you all the time, comrades—as it’s worth doing—because your faith is growing|
     v 3                                |off the charts, and the love which every one of you has towards each other is proliferating, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so much so that we personally are speaking with pride about you in the churches of God because of your|
     v 4                                |perseverance and faith during all the persecutions and extreme difficulties which you endure, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |evidence of the just and fair deliberation of God in deeming you worthy of the kingdom of God, which—incidentally—you|
     v 5                                |suffer for. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |At the end of the day, it’s right in God’s view to pay back those who’re causing you extreme difficulties|
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and for you who are on the receiving end of these extreme difficulties they’re causing to get a payback|
     v 7                                |from God in the form of relief (a relief shared with us) in the revelation of the Lord Jesus from heaven|
     v 7                                |with his almighty angels |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |with a scorching flame of fire meting out vengeance on those who don’t know God and to those who don’t|
     v 8                                |obey the Gospel (i.e., the message) of our Lord Jesus; |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and—indeed—those very people will pay for it in a punishment of doom and destruction issued forth from|
     v 9                                |the face (i.e., scrutinized closely and as a result of that scrutiny issued forth) of the Lord and from|
     v 9                                |the glory of his might (i.e., issued forth by his power manifested in all its magnificent splendor),|
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |when he happens to come to be vested in glory among his saints (i.e., his people) and to be beheld, marveled,|
     v10                                |and admired among all those who have believed—since what we told you to be true in a dead-serious manner|
     v10                                |was believed—on that day.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We also pray all the time for you with this goal in mind: so that our God would deem you worthy of the|
     v11                                |calling you have to be one of His people and would cause all sorts of goodness’s good-will and all sorts|
     v11                                |of deeds of faith in power to proliferate, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that the name (i.e., the reputation) of the our Lord Jesus would be glorified among you, and you in|
     v12                                |him, according to the grace of our God and of our Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS2 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we’re asking you, comrades, on behalf of the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our being rallied|
     v 1                                |to him, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for you not to be jarred from the frame of mind one maintains as a Christian nor be inwardly disturbed|
     v 2                                |or troubled either because of a strong, prevailing attitude, a concept, a piece of information, or a|
     v 2                                |letter you received like one you would receive from us, claiming that the day of the Lord has arrived|
     v 2                                |already. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t let anyone delude you in any way, because it won’t come unless the “apostasy” (i.e., the great|
     v 3                                |falling away from the faith) comes first and the Man of Lawlessness (i.e., the man who’s completely unconstrained|
     v 3                                |by any law, any moral principle, or any godly code defining right and wrong), the Son of Destruction-Causing|
     v 3                                |(i.e., the one who takes it as his personal mission to destroy), is revealed, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the adversary to and the one who raises himself above everything which is said to be God-related or is|
     v 4                                |an object of worship or devotion, so much so that he takes a seat (i.e., he sets up his court, his courtroom,|
     v 4                                |his office) in the temple of God, advertising himself to everyone that he is a god.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t you remember that when I was still staying with you I kept telling you these things? |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And now you know for a fact the thing that restrains him from being revealed in his own time. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact the mystery of this lawlessness is already in action, it’s just that he who restrains him from|
     v 7                                |being revealed at the moment will continue to do so until he happens to disappear from the middle of|
     v 7                                |it all; |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and then the Lawless-One will be revealed, whom the Lord Jesus will put to death by blowing on him and|
     v 8                                |will annihilate him by the outward show of the brilliant splendor of his coming, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |he whose coming is a reflection of Satan in action with all sorts of phony power, signs, and wonders|
     v 9                                |(i.e., miracles; miracles for the purpose of proving one’s legitimacy; awe-inspiring miracles) |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and with every kind of self-delusion which has unrighteousness as its source by those following a trajectory|
     v10                                |of perdition, because they didn’t receive the love of the truth resulting in their being saved (i.e.,|
     v10                                |spared damnation). |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And because of this God will send them an activity of deception with the goal of and resulting in their|
     v11                                |believing in the lie, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that he would be given the opportunity to judge every person who hasn’t believed in the truth but|
     v12                                |has preferred to believe in the unrighteousness of the lie instead.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But we ought to thank God for you all the time, comrades, you who are loved by the Lord, because God|
     v13                                |chose you, His crème de la crème, to salvation (i.e., being spared spiritual and physical destruction)|
     v13                                |in the Holy Spirit and in the true faith. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |With this ends in mind, he called you through our Gospel (i.e. our message) to the acquisition of the|
     v14                                |same type of glory as our Lord Jesus Christ has. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, comrades, stand and keep standing in and get ahold of and keep holding onto the bylaws, code|
     v15                                |of conduct, and best-practices established in perpetuity, which you received whether by a message spoken|
     v15                                |to you in person or through one of our letters. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But our Lord Jesus Christ himself and God our Father, Who loved us and gave us everlasting comfort, consolation,|
     v16                                |and good hope by means of grace, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |will comfort and console your hearts and cause you to stand in every action and in every good affair.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||
    [ THESS2 Chapter 2 has no footnotes ]

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS2 Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In conclusion, pray for us, comrades, so that the word of the Lord would spread rapidly and would be|
     v 1                                |glorified just as it did with you |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and that we would be rescued from the perverse and wicked people who resist us: not everyone follows|
     v 2                                |the Faith, you see. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the Lord is faithful, who will cause us to stand and will guard us from the Evil One. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’ve reached the point where I’m convinced in the Lord of good things where you’re concerned, because|
     v 4                                |you are doing and will do what we charged you with. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the Lord direct your hearts to the love of God and to the steadfastness and endurance of Christ.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we charge you, comrades, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ (i.e., by the authority given to us|
     v 6                                |by Jesus Christ) to stay away from all comrades who conduct themselves with a blatant disregard for the|
     v 6                                |rules which have been set in place and not according to the bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices|
     v 6                                |established in perpetuity which you received from us. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In this regard you know in yourselves from first-hand experience how necessary it is for you to follow|
     v 7                                |our example, since we didn’t disregard the rules when we were among you, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |nor did we mooch any meals from anyone—uh-uh—we were toiling day and night doing back-breaking labor|
     v 8                                |so we wouldn’t be a burden on any of you— |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Not that we don’t have the right to make you provide boarding for us, but we choose to do what we did|
     v 9                                |instead so that we could offer ourselves to you as an example for you to imitate.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And in fact, when we were with you, we kept telling you to obey this rule: If a given person doesn’t|
     v10                                |want to work then don’t let him have a meal at mealtime. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact we hear that there are some people among you going about not following the rules, not doing any|
     v11                                |work but goofing off instead. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To such people we charge and advise in the Lord Jesus Christ certain admonishments so that by keeping|
     v12                                |quiet while working they would eat their own meal (i.e., would be entitled to receive a meal).|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you, comrades—don’t get tired of doing good. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if someone won’t obey the message we’re giving you by this letter were sending, take note of this|
     v14                                |guy: don’t associate with or get mixed up with him, so that he’ll be put to shame. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And don’t think of him as an enemy, but warn and admonish him as a comrade instead.|
 + N V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the Lord of Peace himself grant you the peace throughout every circumstance in every place.|
 +P  V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |May the Lord be with you all.|
 + N V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The greeting written here is in Paul’s handwriting, which is a distinguishing feature of every letter|
     v17                                |I write:|
 +P  V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |<char style="sc">THIS IS THE WAY I WRITE</char>.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus according to the command of God our savior and Christ Jesus our hope:|
 + N V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To Timothy, a genuine son in the Faith:|
 +P  V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace, mercy, peace—from God the Father and from Christ Jesus our Lord.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just as I advised you to remain in Ephesus while on my way to Macedonia so that you would impress upon|
     v 3                                |certain individuals not to go about teaching things which are…shall we say…different |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |or to take myths or endless genealogies seriously (the very things which generate a lot of stupid questions),|
     v 4                                |more seriously than one takes godly stewardship, a stewardship which is by means of faith. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the bottom line of the command that they’re charged with is love from a clean heart and a good conscience,|
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |of which a few people in particular have veered off into a ditch of senseless discussion, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |wanting to be instructors in the Law of Moses, not understanding what they’re saying or the implications|
     v 7                                |of what they insist is true.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we know that the Law is just fine if someone were to use it legitimately, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing this for certain: law (i.e., the Law of Moses in particular or any code of right and wrong for|
     v 9                                |that matter) was put in place for a reason, not for someone who lives right but for the lawless, for|
     v 9                                |those who refuse to submit to authority, for those who aren’t pious, for those who murder their fathers,|
     v 9                                |their mothers, their brothers, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for fornicators (i.e., those who indulge in gross sexual immorality), for homosexuals, kidnappers, liars,|
     v10                                |perjurers, and for anyone who supplants what’s been put into place with something different than healthy|
     v10                                |doctrine, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |doctrine which is in line with the glorious Gospel of the God Who is blessed, doctrine that I’ve been|
     v11                                |entrusted with.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I have grace for my empowerment in Christ Jesus our Lord, since he trusted me enough to make me a minister,|
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |me who used to be a blasphemer, a persecutor, and one who was insolent and violent—but no—He showed mercy|
     v13                                |since I did these things when I didn’t know better while I was in unbelief, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the grace of our Lord proliferated out of bounds with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This statement is trustworthy and from any point of view is worth being accepted: Christ Jesus came into|
     v15                                |the world to save sinners, I myself being the foremost. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In spite of this I was shown mercy, so that in me foremost Christ Jesus would demonstrate every kind|
     v16                                |of patience imaginable, with a view towards those in the future who will be believing in him resulting|
     v16                                |in eternal life.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now to the King of the eternities—to the Incorruptible, Invisible, Singular God—be honor and glory forever|
     v17                                |and ever. Amen (i.e., let us pause a moment for that remark to sink in).|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |These things I’m charging you with, I entrust to you, Timothy my dear son, according to the prophesies|
     v18                                |over you which were given beforehand to lead you on your way, so that you would “serve in the army” so|
     v18                                |to speak among them and be a fine soldier, |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |having faith and a good conscience, which some, having shoved aside things pertaining to the Faith, are|
     v19                                |shipwrecked (i.e., their lives have been devastated), |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |among whom are Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I’ve handed over to Satan so that he would train them (train|
     v20                                |them like one trains a child) not to talk trash or blaspheme.|

     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for kings and for every high-ranking official, so that we may spend our time leading a quiet (i.e., free|
     v 2                                |of disturbances, crises, unrest, etc.) and tranquil life in piety and dignity in every respect. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is a good thing to do, is acceptable, pleasing, and welcomed when examined by God our Savior, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Who wants all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge and understanding of the truth. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that there is one God and there is one mediator between God and mankind, the|
     v 5                                |man Christ Jesus, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who gave himself to be an atonement—the price of redemption; the price to buy someone back—for everyone,|

     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For which I was appointed a preacher and an apostle (i.e., a missionary)—I’m telling you the truth—no|
     v 7                                |lie—an instructor of Gentiles in what true faith really is.|

     v 9                                |judgment combined with self-control, not dress themselves in an exotic hairstyle and with ultra-expensive|
     v 9                                |gold jewelry or pearls or expensive clothing, |

     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Plus Adam was not deceived by the serpent but the woman was deceived, and once deceived, found herself|
     v14                                |in transgression. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But she will be spared calamity through the childbearing years if she were to continue in faith, love,|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You can count on this statement being true: if someone aspires to be a bishop (i.e., a head pastor),|

     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So a bishop candidate must have no moral character flaws; must be the husband of one woman (i.e., not|
     v 2                                |divorced and remarried); self-controlled and exercise moderation in vices such as drinking; be sensible,|
     v 2                                |serious, and level-headed; be respected, held in high esteem, and honorable; be hospitable, able to reach|
     v 2                                |out to others, and likes and can work with people who are different than himself; be capable of giving|
     v 2                                |instructions to others or teaching them; |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |not be a heavy drinker or have a drinking problem; not a bully, a brawler, or someone who gets into fights,|
     v 3                                |but yielding, gentle, courteous, and tolerant instead, and avoids fights; not fondly attached to money;|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: ||
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but if someone can’t preside over his own household, how will he look after God’s household?); |

     v 6                                |true accusations of guilt. |

 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The ministers’ wives must be honorable and respectable as well; not slanderers; self-controlled and exercising|

     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Make sure deacons are the husbands of one wife (i.e., have not been divorced and remarried); do a good|

     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, those who have done a good job serving as a deacon take a big step forward in their own lives|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Chapter 4  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The Spirit says explicitly that in later periods of human history some will revolt from the Faith, their|
     v 1                                |attention occupied by deceiving spirits and doctrines or teachings of demons, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |telling lies in hypocrisy, having reached the point where they’ve seared their own conscience, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |hindering or preventing getting married, abstaining from foods that God created to be taken and consumed|
     v 3                                |with thanksgiving by those who believe and have perceived, recognized, and understood the truth. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And they are free to partake because God’s entire creation is excellent, and nothing which is received|
     v 4                                |with thanksgiving is to be rejected, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |for the food which you eat is designated holy on account of the word of God and on account of a request|
     v 5                                |offered in prayer.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |By teaching the comrades these things until they’re built into them, you’ll be a fine minister of Christ|
     v 6                                |Jesus, firming up the words of the Faith and of the quality teaching which you have closely followed.|
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Refuse to receive things which are profane and desecrated, things which are old wives’ tales. Put yourself|
     v 7                                |on a training program (like you do at the gym) towards building yourself up in piety. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Physical training, you see, is beneficial to a small degree, but piety is beneficial in every respect,|
     v 8                                |holding a promise of life (i.e., that special fullness of life) in the present time and in the time to|
     v 8                                |come.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You can count on that statement I just made being true, and it deserves to be accepted any way you look|
     v 9                                |at it. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact we work hard and strive for this, since we have set our hope on the Living God, Who is the Savior|
     v10                                |of all people, especially those who believe.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Charge the comrades with these things and instruct them in them. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t let anyone think less of you or treat you disrespectfully because you’re young, but instead become|
     v12                                |an example for the believers to follow in speech, in manner, in love, in faith, in purity (and the list|
     v12                                |goes on).|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Stay busy with Scripture reading, with exhortation and encouragement, with teaching (and the list goes|
     v13                                |on) until I get there. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t neglect the spiritual gift in you which was given to you through prophecy and accompanied by the|
     v14                                |laying on of hands by the elders (i.e., the church board). |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Put these things I’m writing to you about into practice; be in them (i.e., be totally into them), so|
     v15                                |that your progress will be quite noticeable to everyone. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pay close attention to yourself—how you are and what you do—and to your doctrine and teaching. Immerse|
     v16                                |yourself in them. You see, by so doing, you’ll be preserving yourself, protecting yourself, and keeping|
     v16                                |yourself from harm, you and those who listen to you.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Chapter 5  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t chide an older man, speaking to him condescendingly, but address him as though he goes by “Mr.”,|
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |an older woman like she’s “Mrs.”, an older teen to twenties male like he’s your comrade, an older teens|
     v 2                                |to twenties female like she’s your woman-comrade but with purity in every respect.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Give financial support to a widow who really is a widow, a woman who is destitute because she has no|
     v 3                                |one to live with to help support her. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if a given widow has children or grandchildren, let the children and grandchildren learn that their|
     v 4                                |highest priority duty is to their household (i.e., those in their immediate family, the ones they currently|
     v 4                                |or used to live with) and that they ought to pay those who were their parents and took care of them growing|
     v 4                                |up back with financial compensation; this is pleasing when put to the close scrutiny of God, you see.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now the widow who’s truly destitute and has reached the point where she’s all alone with no one to take|
     v 5                                |care of her—you’ll find that this sort of woman has set her hope on God, and that she continuously, consistently|
     v 5                                |prays day and night offering up supplications and prayers; |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but the self-indulgent, luxury-seeking, pleasure-loving woman, though living in terms of the medical|
     v 6                                |definition of being alive, has already died.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Give the order that these rules be followed, so that there’d be no way anyone could point a finger at|
     v 7                                |those who follow them. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if someone won’t provide for his own relatives, especially those of his own household, he’s denied|
     v 8                                |the Faith and is worse than an unbeliever.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Enroll a widow into the church support program if she’s not less than sixty years old, the wife of one|
     v 9                                |husband (i.e., not married, divorced, then remarried before being a widow); |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |enroll her if there are eyewitness accounts and testimonies of her good deeds; enroll her if she raised|
     v10                                |children; if she shows hospitality; if she washed the saints’ feet (i.e., done demeaning chores for the|
     v10                                |church and its members); if she helped those in distress; if she’s devoted herself to good works of every|
     v10                                |sort.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But deny requests to enroll widows who are young: you see, when they become overpowered with physical,|
     v11                                |sensual desires contrary to their vow to Christ in their wanting to get married, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |they’ll be “guilty as charged” (so to speak) because they abandoned their previous obligation. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |At the same time they learn to be lazy, making the rounds from house to house—not just lazy but they|
     v13                                |also run at the mouth and stick their noses where they’re not wanted, saying things that shouldn’t be|
     v13                                |said.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So, after thinking about it, I want young widows to get married, have children, and take responsibility|
     v14                                |for their house and for those in it, so they won’t give the Opponent any opportunity to verbally abuse|
     v14                                |them, scolding and insulting them. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that some have already gone in a different direction to become ardent followers|
     v15                                |of Satan. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a particular woman who is a believer has widows in her care, have her help them and not be a burden|
     v16                                |on the church, so that the ones who really are widows and are destitute as such may be helped.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let the elders (i.e., those on the church board) who do a good job of running things be entitled to twice|
     v17                                |their pay, especially those who work hard at speaking and teaching. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the Scripture says “do not muzzle the ox while threshing” and “the worker is entitled to his|
     v18                                |paycheck.”|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t accept an accusation of wrongdoing against an elder except if it’s leveled by two or three people|
     v19                                |who solemnly swear that it’s true.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Expose those who are sinners in front of everyone, so that everyone will become afraid of sinning.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I solemnly affirm these things and declare them to be true before God, Christ Jesus, and the special|
     v21                                |angels, so that you would guard these things without prejudice, doing nothing out of favoritism.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t be too eager to lay hands on anyone and thereby make them a minister nor should you participate|
     v22                                |in others’ sins: keep yourself unsullied.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t just drink water only anymore, but use a little wine as a medicine of a sort because of your stomach|
     v23                                |and your frequent ailments.|
 +   V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For some people, their sins are obvious, paraded before them with much fanfare for everyone to see in|
     v24                                |front of them on their way to judgment; but some come right behind them, quietly, unannounced, and unexpected|
     v24                                |by everyone. |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Deeds operate the same way that I just described about sin: the deeds which are exemplary are obvious|
     v25                                |to everyone, but the ones which are otherwise can’t be kept hidden.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Chapter 6  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Anyone at all who’s forced to be a slave, let him esteem his master worthy of total honor, so that God’s|
     v 1                                |reputation and the things the church believes in not be bad-mouthed. |
   N V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They who have masters who are believers mustn’t despise them because they’re fellow-comrades, but should|
     v 2                                |serve them all the more, because they are faithful and beloved, they who are having a surrogate take|
     v 2                                |their place in assisting them in what’s beneficial.|
 +P  V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Give instructions in these matters and exhort and encourage them to follow them. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If anyone teaches things which are…shall we say…different, and isn’t headed in the direction of delivering|
     v 3                                |sound messages, namely messages of our Lord Jesus Christ and teaching in line with godliness, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |then he’s become conceited, understanding nothing, but has a sick desire for debates and controversies|
     v 4                                |instead, out of which he becomes envious, engages in quarrelling and strife, he slanders, becomes paranoid,|
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |constantly arguing with people who are morally depraved whose mind is also deprived of the truth, of|
     v 5                                |the opinion that godliness is a means of gain—|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |—But godliness with contentment alongside it actually is a means of great gain. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We brought nothing with us into the world when we were born, you see, and we sure can’t take anything|
     v 7                                |out of it. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Regular meals and adequate clothing—we’ll be satisfied with these things. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But those who want and plan to get richer and richer fall into temptation, into a trap, and into many|
     v 9                                |strong desires which are unintelligent, dull-witted, and harmful. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that a potential root-cause of every type of the evils you see in the world|
     v10                                |is the love of money, which some who’ve made it their goal to get rich have veered off from the Faith|
     v10                                |and have skewered themselves through with a spit (like when roasting meat), skewering themselves all|
     v10                                |over with a lot of misery, with many mental pains, and with a tremendous amount of undue suffering.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now you, oh man of God—run away as fast as you can from these things. Pursue righteousness, piety, faith,|
     v11                                |love, patience, gentleness, and the list goes on. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Fight the good fight of the Faith. Grab and hold onto that special fullness of life, eternal life, to|
     v12                                |which ends you were called and for which you confessed the Good Confession before many witnesses.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I charge you before God the Life-Causer of everything and Christ Jesus who submitted the Good Confession|
     v13                                |as testimony to Pontius Pilate |

     v16                                |in).|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Charge those who are rich in this present age not to be high-minded or to set their hope on the uncertainty|

     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and makes these things available to us so we can be doing good things to others, so that we can become|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, a menial servant of God but yet an apostle (i.e., a missionary) of Jesus Christ according to the|
     v 1                                |Faith of God’s chosen people and the recognition of the truth which is reflective of godliness |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which rests upon a living hope of eternal life, which the God Who Won’t Lie promised before time immemorial—|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But He manifested His word in individual periods of human history by means of preaching, preaching that|
     v 3                                |I was entrusted with according to the commandment of God our Savior:|
 + N V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To Titus, a real son according to the common Faith:|
 +P  V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace and peace from the Father God and Christ Jesus our savior.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The reason I left you behind in Crete is so that you would tidy up the remaining items and would go from|
     v 5                                |city to city and appoint elders (i.e., church board members) like I told you to do. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a given candidate is without moral flaws, the husband of one wife (i.e., not divorced and remarried),|
     v 6                                |the children he has are trustworthy, not ones who can be fairly accused of having a reckless disregard|
     v 6                                |for their own self-preservation or of being rebellious, then he’s met the minimum qualifications to be|
     v 6                                |an elder.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, a bishop (i.e., a head pastor), as the steward of God’s house, must be without moral flaws;|
     v 7                                |not stubborn or self-willed; not hot-tempered; not a heavy drinker; not pugnacious or a bully; not always|
     v 7                                |trying to make a fast buck through shady business practices; |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but instead hospitable, able to reach out to others, one who likes and can work with people who are different|
     v 8                                |than himself; a lover of all things good; sensible, serious, and level-headed; just and fair; holy; self-controlled,|
     v 8                                |disciplined, and having one’s impulses under control; |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |clinging to the tried-and-true message reflective of the doctrine we teach, so that he’d be capable of|
     v 9                                |both exhorting and encouraging others in the Sound Doctrine and correcting those who oppose it.|
 +   V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that there are those who refuse to submit to authority, those who say nothing|
     v10                                |when they speak and who are deceivers, especially those who came out of the circumcision (i.e., those|
     v10                                |whose background was that they were following the Law of Moses), |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who must be silenced, people in particular who subvert entire households, teaching things they mustn’t|
     v11                                |for morally unacceptable gain. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |One of their own prophets said, “Cretans are always liars, vicious brutes, and fat blimps.” |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m quoting a reliable source. You must severely correct them for this reason: so that they’ll be healthy|
     v13                                |in the Faith; |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so they won’t pay any attention to Jewish fables and to the commandments of people who are turning them|
     v14                                |away from the truth.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All things are clean (i.e., according to the Law of Moses, eligible to be touched, handled, and used;|
     v15                                |absent any defilement) to those who are clean; but to those who have been defiled (i.e., who’ve become|
     v15                                |tainted and are no longer clean) and who refuse to believe, nothing is pure—no, not a chance—both their|
     v15                                |minds and their consciences have come to be defiled. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They profess to know God, but their profession is repudiated by their actions, as these people are detestable,|
     v16                                |disobedient, and failures when comes to any good deed.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||
    [ TITUS Chapter 1 has no footnotes ]

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now talk in a way that makes sound doctrine more pronounced and more palatable.|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I expect the older men to be self-controlled and to exercise moderation in vices such as drinking; to|
     v 2                                |be honorable and respectable; to be sensible, serious, and level-headed; healthy in faith, love, perseverance.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Likewise, older women should behave in a reverent manner; not be slanderers; not have reached the point|
     v 3                                |where they have a compulsion to drink a lot; be ones who teach others to strive for excellence, |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that they could train the young women to maintain a discipline of sensibility and self-control which|
     v 4                                |causes them to have a strong friendship with their husbands and enjoy their companionship, and train|
     v 4                                |them to do the same for their children; |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to be sensible, serious, and level-headed; to be chaste; to be good housekeepers and homemakers, submitting|
     v 5                                |to their husbands, so that the word of God not be spoken badly of.|
 +   V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Likewise, I exhort and encourage the young men to be sensible, serious, and level-headed |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in every aspect of their life, putting yourself out there as an example of a lifestyle characterized|
     v 7                                |by fine deeds; to be incorruptible in their adherence to the teaching of Christianity; to be dignified;|
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to have wholesome speech which is unassailable to accusation, so the opposition camp would be humiliated|
     v 8                                |by not having anything bad to say about them.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I exhort and encourage slaves to submit to their masters in all respects; to be pleasing and to not give|
     v 9                                |their masters any backtalk; |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to not go around stealing things, but to instead demonstrate that they’re good people and can be trusted|
     v10                                |in every regard, so that slaves acting this way would in every regard be a feather in the cap (so to|
     v10                                |speak) of the teaching of God our Savior.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, the grace of God, which is salvation, shined to all people, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |training us to deny the ungodliness and the strong, worldly desires, so we would live in the present|
     v12                                |age sensibly, with self-control, justly, and godly, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |awaiting the blessed hope and the appearance of the glory of our Great God and of our savior Christ Jesus,|
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who gave himself for us so that he would redeem us (i.e., recover for us what we once had) from any sort|
     v14                                |of wickedness and lawlessness (i.e., a refusal to be restrained by the rules of God or of man) and clean|
     v14                                |and purify for himself a special people, ones who have a zeal for doing good works.|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Communicate these things and encourage, exhort, and correct while staying in full control of the situation:|
     v15                                |don’t let anyone look down on you.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Keep reminding them to submit to and comply with rulers who have legitimate authority over you and to|
     v 1                                |be prepared to do any sort of good deed |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |without saying bad things about what you’re having to do, not being quarrelsome when you’re doing it,|
     v 2                                |not being inflexible about every little detail—in every way possible demonstrating a gentleness towards|
     v 2                                |people borne out of self-restraint.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, we were mindless back then, disobedient, deceived, enslaved to a variety of strong desires|
     v 3                                |(including sexual desires) and pleasures, spending our lives in malice, in envy, detestable people hating|
     v 3                                |each other. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But when the goodness and benevolence of God our Savior shined on us, |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |it did not originate out of things we did in a state of righteousness, but He saved us instead according|
     v 5                                |to His mercy on account of a washing of the new birth and a renewal of the Holy Spirit, |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |which He poured out on us copiously through Jesus Christ our savior, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |so that, having been made righteous in that grace, we heirs would be born to a hope of eternal life (i.e.,|
     v 7                                |that special fullness of life).|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You can count on this statement being true: I’ve thought about these things, and what I want you to do|
     v 8                                |is to emphasize them, so that those who have come to believe in God would be intent on prioritizing good|
     v 8                                |works. These things I’m having you do are good and benefit the people. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But do your best to avoid stupid debates, obsessions with genealogies, and conflicts and fights over|
     v 9                                |law (i.e., from a conceptual perspective, over a codified list of God’s commandments, in particular the|
     v 9                                |Law of Moses), for they are useless and pointless. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Shun a heretic (i.e., a person who breaks people off from the accepted doctrine or school of thought|
     v10                                |and forms a sect out of them) after giving him two clear warnings, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing from firsthand experience that that kind of person is twisted, has no morals, and is sinning,|
     v11                                |being condemned for what’s going on inside of himself.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When I do send Artemis to you or maybe Tychicus, as fast as you can come visit me in Nicopolis, since|
     v12                                |I’ve decided to spend the winter there. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Send Zenas the lawyer and Apollos on their journey as soon as you can, and check with them first so that|
     v13                                |they don’t leave without taking something they need.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But let our own people also learn to emphasize good works that have the goal of meeting the needs of|
     v14                                |others, so that they’re not unproductive with their time and resources.|
 + N V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Everyone with me sends their greetings. Greet those who love us in faith.|
 +P  V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of God be with you all.|

 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, a slave of Christ Jesus, and Comrade Timothy:|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To Philemon, our dear fellow worker, |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to Apphia our female comrade, to Archippus our fellow soldier, and to the church that meets in your house.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Grace be to you and peace from our Father God and the Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m always thanking my God as I bring you up in prayer, |

     v 5                                |those who are believers), |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to the ends that the sharing and participation of your faith—a sharing and participation which is in|
     v 6                                |operation—should manifest itself in a recognition and better understanding of all the good which is in|
     v 6                                |you with Christ as the goal. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, I got a lot of joy and encouragement out of your love, because the saints have been refreshed|
     v 7                                |deep down on the inside because of you, comrade.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |With this in mind, I have the audacity in Christ to order you to do your duty by doing what’s right—|
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Through the love of God I appeal to you all the more in such a personage as an old man named Paul who|
     v 9                                |is also now but a slave of Christ Jesus— |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I appeal to you concerning my son, who was born into slavery as Onesimus, |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who used to be of no use to you but is quite useful to me at this time, |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |who is the same person I sent back to you (in other words, I’m talking about those things which are nearest|
     v12                                |and dearest to my heart), |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |whom I was planning on retaining for myself so that he could serve me under your sponsorship while I’m|
     v13                                |imprisoned because of the Gospel.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I didn’t want to do anything without your consent, so that your act of goodness will not have been granted|
     v14                                |as though you had no choice but because you authorized it. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of this, in fact, without delay he was sent away from me for a short period of time so that you|
     v15                                |would send him away from you forever, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |sending him away as someone who’s no longer a slave but sending him away for the benefit of someone who|
     v16                                |is a slave, dear comrade, especially for my benefit, but how much more for your benefit both in the flesh|
     v16                                |(i.e., from a natural perspective) and in the Lord?|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So if you’re all in with me, welcome him and treat him as you would me. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If he did something wrong to you or owes you any money, put it on my tab. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I Paul personally wrote this in my own handwriting so you’ll be assured that this letter is genuinely|
     v19                                |from me: I’ll pay you back whatever he owes—But don’t get me going about how you owe me your very life.|
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Yes, comrade, do me this favor in the Lord: In Christ bring to rest what is churning deep inside my heart.|
 +   V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I wrote to you convinced of your obedience, having come to know firsthand that you will even do for me|
     v21                                |what I tell you. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But at the same time, prepare a guest room for me; you see, I’m also hoping that I’ll be the beneficiary|
     v22                                |of your generosity in you allowing me to stay with you on account of your many requests to have me over.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, says hello, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |along with my coworkers Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke.|
 +   V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with you all’s spirit.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of this confusion between angels and the Son of God, it’s even more necessary for us to pay attention|

     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |how will we evade a just punishment after neglecting so great a salvation (i.e., an entire program of|

     v 3                                |which was accepted and wholeheartedly embraced way back then by those who listened to it as it was being|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For this reason, brothers (i.e., fellow comrades), saints (i.e., those God has separated to Himself),|

     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but just one time a year the high priest entered the inner sanctuary, but not without taking blood with|
     v 7                                |him, blood that he offered on behalf of himself and on behalf of the sins that the folk-people unknowingly|
     v 7                                |committed. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is what the Holy Spirit is signifying: while the outer sanctuary still exists and is being actively|
     v 8                                |used, the way into the Holy of Holies has not yet been revealed, |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |a particular concept which is analogous to the period of time which has arrived and is presently in operation,|
     v 9                                |which according to this analogy means that the offering up of offerings and sacrifices is powerless to|
     v 9                                |bring those performing the rituals to completeness along the lines of conscience; |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |the regulations involved with eating, drinking, various kinds of ceremonial washings were physical and|
     v10                                |self-originated acts only, imposed until a period of reform happened to arrive and change things.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Christ showed up as a high priest of the good things which came into being because of the greater and|
     v11                                |more perfect tabernacle, which is not hand-made (in other words, not of this planet). |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It was not by the blood of goats and calves but by his own blood that he entered once and for all into|
     v12                                |the Holy of Holies and obtained eternal release and deliverance from sin. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, if the blood of bulls and goats and the sprinkling of the ashes of an incinerated heifer make|
     v13                                |those who’ve been defiled pristine and undefiled again to the producing of the purity of the flesh, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the Eternal Spirit offered himself without blemish|
     v14                                |to God, cleanse your conscience from dead works resulting in you serving the Living God?|
 +   V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Because of this, he’s the mediator of a new covenant, so that, considering that a death occurred for|
     v15                                |the redemption (i.e., the settling of something; fixing what’s broken) of the transgressions which were|
     v15                                |committed under the first covenant, those who’ve been called to be God’s people would partake of the|
     v15                                |eternal inheritance (i.e., the things God has immutably and irrevocably reserved for them and intended|
     v15                                |for them to have). |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that where a last will and testament (which is what a covenant is) is concerned,|
     v16                                |it’s necessary that the death of the will’s testator be proven legally. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, upon the death of the testator the will is frozen as-is and can no longer be amended in any|
     v17                                |way; it never has that immutability-strength while the testator is still alive and therefore able to|
     v17                                |amend it at any time. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Hence, the first covenant was not instituted apart from the inclusion of blood. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, once every commandment in the Law was spoken to all the people by Moses, taking the blood of|
     v19                                |calves and goats mixed with water, red wool, and hyssop, he sprinkled the scroll he read from itself|
     v19                                |and all the people |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |while saying, “This is the blood of the covenant which God commanded you to keep.&quot; |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In addition he sprinkled the tabernacle and all the serving vessels used in the rituals in blood the|
     v21                                |same way. |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It’s almost as though it’s an Old Testament axiom that according to the Law of Moses everything is purified|
     v22                                |and cleansed by blood, and apart from the shedding of blood any sort of forgiveness of sin doesn’t happen.|
 +   V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While the copies of the things in the spirit-world (i.e., the copies being the earthly tabernacle and|
     v23                                |items in it) need to be cleansed by these things (i.e., by the blood of calves, of goats, etc.), but|
     v23                                |the actual things in the spirit-world that the earthly things are a copy of require better sacrifices|
     v23                                |than the ones offered on earth. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, Christ didn’t enter a Holy of Holies that was created by human hands, these man-made things|
     v24                                |merely being symbolic representations and mirror-copies of the real things, but instead entered into|
     v24                                |the same thing (i.e., the thing which the symbolic representations are based on) which is in the spirit-world,|
     v24                                |to be seen by, to be known by, and to be subjected to God’s intense scrutiny on our behalf. |
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Nor is it the case that he repetitively brings himself into this Holy of Holies in the spirit-world just|
     v25                                |like the high priest enters the earthly Holy of Holies each year with another batch of blood to be sprinkled.|
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If that were the case, he would have to suffer and die on the cross many times starting the moment the|
     v26                                |human race began; but at this this critical moment in the annuls of history, he appeared this once for|
     v26                                |the obliteration of the sin of mankind because of his sacrifice having been disclosed and made known|
     v26                                |to everyone. |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And reflective of the fact that it’s been allocated that every person in the human race undergo death|
     v27                                |once and only once and after this undergo judgment, |
     V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in the same way as this, Christ, having been brought forth one time only for the purpose of being offered|
     v28                                |up for the sins of the many, will be seen a second time apart from sin (i.e., he’ll make a second appearance,|
     v28                                |and this appearance will have nothing to do with atoning for sins) by those who assiduously and eagerly|
     v28                                |look to him for salvation (i.e., look to him to protect them from potential harm, whatever that might|
     v28                                |be).|

 + N V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |You see, whom the Lord loves He disciplines,|
 +PN V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |And He thrashes every son|

 +   V--            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +   V 7 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |You endure for the purpose of being molded by discipline into the person you need to become: God treats|
     v 7                                |you like you are His son. In this regard, can you think of any son whom his father doesn’t discipline?|
     V 8 VERSES_NON_INDENTED_NARRATIVE: |But if you live in absence of discipline, which you all get your fair share of now, then you’re children|
     v 8                                |some strange woman had out of wedlock and not sons who are included in the family.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Furthermore, we had fathers in the natural who disciplined us time and time again, and we gave them our|

     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, while it’s true that for a brief period our natural fathers disciplined us the way they personally|
     v10                                |thought discipline ought to be done, but He, though, disciplines us for our own benefit, for the purpose|
     v10                                |of us being able to partake of His holiness on an ongoing basis. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |While any discipline at the time it’s occurring is not considered to be a bundle of joy, but instead|
     v11                                |is painful, later on it yields a peaceful result, namely righteousness, to those who have been trained|
     v11                                |by the discipline they received.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, put the hands that lie idle at your side and the knees which have become weak back|
     v12                                |in the position where they’re poised for action, |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and clear out a straight path for your feet, so that the hip joint, knee joint, etc. which is preventing|
     v13                                |you from walking not be dislocated any more, but rather be healed.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pursue peace with all people, and pursue holiness, without which no one will see the Lord. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Check up on any person who might lack the grace of God (i.e., who needs to receive mercy, kindness, or|
     v15                                |forgiveness from God) and help them in whatever situation they’re in which is causing this, lest some|
     v15                                |root of bitterness grow up and become a source of irritation, annoyance, or trouble, and many people|
     v15                                |would be tainted by this root; |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |lest there be some fornicator metaphorically speaking (i.e., someone who’s immoral in a way which is|
     v16                                |analogous to sexually immorality) or someone who’s profane or has no piety like Esau, who sold what was|
     v16                                |rightfully his by birth for one meal. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, you know the story, how afterwards, while wanting to receive his inheritance through the blessing|
     v17                                |bestowed by Isaac, he was rejected; the simple fact is that there was no way he could turn the situation|
     v17                                |around, although with tears on his face he tried.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is that you haven’t come to a physically tangible mountain like Mount Sinai, to|
     v18                                |one which is on fire, and to darkness and to gloom and to a whirlwind |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to the sound of a trumpet and to a voice speaking words, a voice which those who heard it begged|
     v19                                |that not another word be spoken to them; |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, they couldn’t take it anymore, couldn’t stand the order, “If so much as an animal happens to|
     v20                                |touch the mountain, it will be stoned to death.” |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The scene was so terrifying that Moses said, “I’m terrified and shaking all over”—|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |—No, you’ve come to Mount Zion and to the city of the Living God, the Jerusalem in heaven, and to a myriad|
     v22                                |of angels, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |to the mother of all church gatherings of the firstborn who’s registered in heaven, and to God the judge|
     v23                                |of all, and to spirits of upright, decent people who’ve been made perfect, |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and to Jesus the mediator of a new covenant and to the true sprinkling-blood, which calls for better|
     v24                                |things than the blood of Abel which cried out from the ground.|
 +   V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |See to it that no one disregards or rejects what’s being called for. You see, if those people who disregarded|
     v25                                |or rejected what was called for couldn’t escape after He warned them when they were on the Earth, how|
     v25                                |much more will they not escape, they who refuse Him Who warns from heaven? |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That voice shook the Earth back then, but at the present time there’s a promise which He has given which|
     v26                                |says, “I will yet cause the Earth to shake one more time, and not just shake the Earth but the sky, outer|
     v26                                |space, and the spirit-world too.” |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the phrase “yet one more time” insinuates the removal of those things which are shaken, as they are|
     v27                                |things which have been created, so that what would remain would be the things which can’t be shaken.|
 +   V28              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, as we heartily embrace a kingdom which can’t be shaken, let us maintain an attitude|
     v28                                |of thankfulness, one in which we serve God in a way that pleases Him, keeping it with reverence and awe:|
     V29              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For our God is a consuming fire.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  HEB Chapter 13  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Continue in your love for your fellow comrade, loving the fellowship you have with them. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t neglect to extend a hearty friendship-welcome to those who are new to a church, new to the area,|
     v 2                                |or who are just plain different than yourselves. In doing this, some have unwittingly welcomed angels.|
 +   V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Remember those who are in prison as though you’re fellow inmates, and remember those who are ill-treated|
     v 3                                |as though you have to live in their shoes.|
 +   V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be sure to honor the institution of marriage and be sure that what you do in bed is morally pure; for|
     v 4                                |God will judge fornicators and adulterers.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be sure that the kind of life you live is absent the love of money; He himself said, “There’s no way|
     v 5                                |I’ll ever leave you or forsake you.” |
   N V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This gives us confidence so much so that we perk up and have the gumption to say,|
 +PN V 6            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |The Lord is my helper; I will not fear.|
 +P  V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |What can a person do to me?|

 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Remember your leaders, the very people who spoke the word of God to you, closely observe on a continual|
     v 7                                |basis the end-result of their manner of life—mimic their faith.|
 +   V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t get sidetracked by different and novel teachings; you see, it’s good that the heart be established|
     v 9                                |by grace, not by teachings about what food we should or shouldn’t eat. These teachings haven’t benefited|
     v 9                                |those who have changed their lifestyles to follow them. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We have a spiritual altar, and they who serve by performing the religious rituals in the physical tabernacle|
     v10                                |are not entitled to eat the food which is a byproduct of the sacrifices offered upon it. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, the carcasses of the animals whose blood is brought by the high priest into the Holy of Holies|
     v11                                |are incinerated outside the camp, out away from where everybody lived. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, Jesus also, so that through his own blood he would purify, sanctify, and make the folk-people|
     v12                                |holy, suffered outside of the gates of the city away from where everybody lived. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So then, let’s go outside the camp where everybody lives and go to him, pick up his vilification, vituperation,|
     v13                                |and reviling, and carry it ourselves.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, here on this planet we don’t have a city for us to live in which is going to last into eternity,|
     v14                                |but we’re seeking after the city to come instead. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Through him let us continuously offer up to God a sacrificial offering consisting of praise, in other|
     v15                                |words, the fruit of lips which confess words in his name and to his name (i.e., by his authority and|
     v15                                |to his glory). |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And don’t neglect to do acts of kindness and to help others financially; for God is quite pleased with|
     v16                                |sacrificial offerings such as these.|
 +   V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be persuaded by your leaders to the point of obeying them and submit to them; you see, they keep watch|
     v17                                |over your very lives, as they’ll be held accountable for them. But submit so that they may do their job|
     v17                                |with joy and not regress into grumbling; it just isn’t worth it.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Pray for us, and keep on praying for us. We believe that we have a good conscience (i.e., we’re not involved|
     v18                                |in any wrongdoing; there’s nothing we feel guilty about) in that we are wanting to maintain a lifestyle|
     v18                                |of excellence in every respect. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But more importantly, I encourage you to pray so that I’ll be restored to you (i.e., be reinstated and|
     v19                                |continue doing with you what I was doing) as soon as possible.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now may the God of peace, Who brought the Great Shepherd of the Sheep back from the dead by means of|
     v20                                |the blood of the eternal covenant—our Lord Jesus Christ— |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |in every good way put you into proper order and prepare you for a purpose, doing this with the goal of|
     v21                                |accomplishing His will, working in us what from His point of view is very pleasing through Jesus Christ,|
     v21                                |to whom be the glory forever and ever. Let us pause for a moment to let that sink in.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Bear with me, comrades, as I encourage you with this word of encouragement. You see, I’ve only briefly|
     v22                                |written to you about my personal affairs. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Just so you know, our fellow comrade Timothy has been let out of jail. If he can manage to come over|
     v23                                |to where I am in a hurry, I’ll take him with me when I visit you.|

     v24                                |Those from the Roman province of Italy greet you.|
