  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |James, a servant/slave of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ:|
 +PN V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To the blood-descendants of the twelve tribes of Israel who are among the Diaspora (i.e. the scattering|
     v 1                                |of Jews all over the world):|
 +P  V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m delighted to write to you:|
 +   V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Consider it a joy, my dear comrades, when you by chance fall into various tests and trials which find|
     v 2                                |out what you’re made of, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |knowing that the process of proving your faith produces perseverance. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Let perseverance have the opportunity to become a mature, completed work, in order that you would become|
     v 4                                |mature and that every part of you would become complete with nothing left out.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But speaking of things which are left out…If someone is lacking in wisdom, advise him to simply ask for|
     v 5                                |wisdom from the giving-God who’ll grant the request without chewing the person out or demeaning him,|
     v 5                                |and it will be given to him. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But admonish him to ask in faith, nothing about him wavering in doubt: you see, a person who doubts is|
     v 6                                |like the way that ocean waves are moved and tossed about by the wind. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |To this point, you should adjust that person’s expectations so that he does not expect to receive anything|
     v 7                                |from the Lord, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |since he is a double-minded man, irresolute in all his ways.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Get the Humiliated, Abased Person to glory and take pride in his exaltation, |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and likewise get the rich man to practice humility and self-abasement, because, like the wild flowers|
     v10                                |of the field which reach an apex when they blossom and then fade back into obscurity, he too will have|
     v10                                |his moment in the sun then pass away and fade back into obscurity. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the sun rose and dried out the wild flower with its sweltering heat, its flower-part fell off,|
     v11                                |and the lovely appearance it projected was destroyed—this is the same way that the rich man will waste|
     v11                                |away in his journey through life.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Blessed is the man who perseveres over the course of tests and trials, since, after he’s attained approval|
     v12                                |because of his perseverance, he’ll receive the trophy of a deeply satisfying life, which is promised|
     v12                                |to those who love Him. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Teach the person who’s being tested by some sort of trial or temptation not to say, “I’m being tested|
     v13                                |by God to see if there’s any evil in me.” You see, God is un-tempt-able by any evil; He tempts no one.|
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Each person is tempted when he’s lured and dragged off by the passions which are peculiar to him and|
     v14                                |not necessarily to the next person. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Then once passion or desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin. When it’s finished running its course,|
     v15                                |sin produces death (i.e., stagnation of waste, joylessness, futility, and destruction).|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t get led down the primrose path, my dear comrades. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Every good gift and every perfect present is from the sky above, coming down from the Creator of Astronomical|
     v17                                |Objects (i.e. the sun, the moon, stars, etc.), with whom there is no deviation in the movement of such|
     v17                                |objects and no hint or suggestion of change to them. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Having planned and decided to do so, he birthed us in a conceptualization of truth with the end-goal|
     v18                                |of us being the crème de la crème of His creation.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be sure you get this down pat, my dear comrades: Each person should see to it that he’s quick to listen,|
     v19                                |slow to speak, slow to anger. |
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, a man’s anger won’t live up to God’s standards of right and wrong. |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In light of this, once you’ve rid yourself of any filthy residue of malice, with a soft-spoken, gentle|
     v21                                |self-restraint take to heart and fully embrace the implanted word of God which is able to relieve, rescue,|
     v21                                |and preserve your mind and emotions.|
 +   V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But become practitioners of a given subject matter and not just students who hear it taught, deceiving|
     v22                                |themselves because they listen but won’t do, |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |because if somebody hears a subject lectured to him but doesn’t put it into practice, that guy’s like|
     v23                                |a man who looks at himself in a mirror and gets an idea of what he looks like— |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you see, he got an idea of what he looks likes, walked away, and immediately forgot what he looks like.|
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the fellow who crouched down and looked carefully at a perfect code, a freedom code, and stays put|
     v25                                |looking at it and didn’t become a forgetting-student but became a doing-practitioner, that fellow will|
     v25                                |be blessed in his doing.|
 +   V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If anyone thinks that he strictly adheres to the do’s and don’ts of his religion and isn’t reigning in|
     v26                                |his tongue but instead kids himself into believing he follows his religion strictly—this sort of religion|
     v26                                |is worthless. |
     V27              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |A pure set of religious do’s and don’ts—a set that’s untainted from the Father-God’s point of view—is|
     v27                                |to visit orphans and widows in dire need for the purpose of helping them, while keeping oneself unstained|
     v27                                |from the world, i.e. the established order of humanity which wants nothing to do with God.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My comrades, don’t have a faith in our Lord of Glory Jesus Christ which shows favoritism. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a powerful businessman wearing an expensive suit were to join your synagogue, and a poor man in ragged|
     v 2                                |clothing were to join, |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |you’d be naturally inclined to favor the fellow in the expensive suit and tell him, “Let’s make sure|
     v 3                                |you’re seated up front in the reserved section where all the important people sit,” and you would tell|
     v 3                                |the poor guy, “Stand against the wall in the back or sit where the usher sits and be ready to fill in|
     v 3                                |for him and run an errand when we call.” |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Have you not shown bias towards those among you, preferring one person over another, and have you not|
     v 4                                |become decision-makers whose thought process consists of really bad, downright evil, things?|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Listen, my dear comrades: Hasn’t God chosen the world’s poor to be rich in faith and to get their individual|
     v 5                                |slice of God’s involvement with the human race, which He promised to those who love Him? |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But you’ve treated the poor with contempt. Don’t the rich oppress you and drag you into court? |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t they cuss at, slander, and revile your excellent, hard-earned reputation? |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If there really is a perfect regal code which we live by and if the code is based on the Bible verse|
     v 8                                |which says, “Love your neighbor as yourself,” then you’re on the right track. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if you show favoritism, you’re committing a sin and are incriminated by the Law of Moses. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, that particular individual who’s willingly trying to keep the Law but falls short in one area|
     v10                                |is guilty of violating it as a whole.|
 +   V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Here’s an example: the same Old Testament Law which said “Don’t commit adultery” also said “Don’t commit|
     v11                                |murder.” Now if you didn’t commit adultery but committed murder, you nevertheless became a Law-violator,|
     v11                                |violating the Law as a whole even though you violated just one part of it. |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Talk and behave as though as though you’re going to be held to a standard defined by freedom’s code and|
     v12                                |judged by it. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the judgment that you will eventually face will be merciless towards those who won’t show mercy.|
     v13                                |Mercy trumps judgment.|
 +   V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |What benefit is it, my comrades, if (using some person for the purpose of illustration) this person says|
     v14                                |he has faith but has no actions which normally accompany it? That sort of so-called faith won’t pull|
     v14                                |him out of a bad situation, will it? |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If a comrade were to find himself or herself having no clothing whatsoever to protect his or her body|
     v15                                |with and lacking minimum-sustenance food, |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and if you were to tell him, “See you later, take care now. Stay warm and get plenty to eat,” but not|
     v16                                |provide physical necessities for him, what good is that? |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The sort of faith we’re talking about here is the same way: if it were to not have actions which normally|
     v17                                |accompany it, it would be void of life, being in a state which is consistent with itself.|
 +   V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Putting that aside now—someone is bound to say, “You have faith but no actions to go along with it and|
     v18                                |I have actions but no faith to go along with them.” Show me your kind of faith apart from the actions|
     v18                                |which normally accompany it, and I’ll show you the genuine kind of faith from out of my actions. |
     V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You believe that there is only one true God and that He is of one mind and has His own will, and there|
     v19                                |is no other being comparable to Him? Good job. The demons believe it as well and quiver in their boots|
     v19                                |over it.|
 +   V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Oh you nit-wit—were you interested in knowing that the sort of faith which is apart from actions which|
     v20                                |normally accompany it amounts to nothing? |
     V21              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Wasn’t our patriarch Abraham made right in God’s sight from actions after offering his son Isaac upon|
     v21                                |the altar? |
     V22              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In the case of Abraham offering Isaac, one sees that the genuine sort of faith operates together with|
     v22                                |its accompanying actions and comes to fruition out of the actions. |
     V23              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The verse of Scripture was fulfilled which says, “Abraham believed in God, and it wound up being credited|
     v23                                |to him as righteousness,” and he was called a friend and close-companion of God. |
     V24              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Observe that a person is made right in God’s sight as the result of actions and not by faith on its own.|
     V25              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Wasn’t the prostitute Rahab made right in God’s sight the same way—as the result of actions—cooperating|
     v25                                |with the agents and hurrying them out another way? |
     V26              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For as the body is dead when it is apart from a spirit, in the same way the genuine sort of faith apart|
     v26                                |from works is dead too.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 3  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |There should not be a lot of you becoming instructors, my comrades, knowing that we’ll be held to a higher|
     v 1                                |standard. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we all mess up or fall short in many ways. If a given person doesn’t mess up in speech, that|
     v 2                                |fellow has got his act together, able to reign in his entire body as well. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now we stick bits in the mouths of horses in order to prevail upon them to do our bidding, and in doing|
     v 3                                |so we guide their entire bodies. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Ships too, for example, are gigantic and are propelled by stiff breezes, guided by the smallest thing|
     v 4                                |imaginable—a rudder—in whatever heading the helmsman selects. |
   N V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Analogous to this, the tongue is a small part of a much larger unit and makes outrageous remarks.|
 +P  V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I’m telling you what, it’s like they say: “Just a tiny flame can set even an enormous forest on fire.”|
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the tongue is a flame indeed, an elaborate mechanism of wrong-doing—the tongue occupies a position|
     v 6                                |of preeminence among our body parts—the defiler of the entire body and stoker of the Merry-go-round of|
     v 6                                |Life—and is itself stoked by hell.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, human beings by nature tame wild animals. All sorts—land, aquatic, reptilian—are in the process|
     v 7                                |of being tamed and have been tamed, |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |but not a single person can tame the restless, unstable tongue, full of deadly poison. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |With it we thank the Father-God and with it we swear at our fellow man, those who have been created in|
     v 9                                |the image of God. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Out of the same mouth come thanksgiving and cussing. This is not the way it’s supposed to be, my comrades.|
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Non-contaminated and contaminated water doesn’t pour out of the same spring, now does it? |
     V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |It’s not possible, my comrades, for a fig tree to yield olives or a grape vine figs, or for a water source|
     v12                                |to produce both salt water and fresh water, is it?|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Who among you is wise and understanding? Let him display his deeds which come from the good conduct of|
     v13                                |one who follow’s God’s commandments in wisdom’s gentleness. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if you have bitter jealousy and rivalry in your heart, don’t distort the truth by bragging and lying.|
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is not the same wisdom which comes from the spiritual world where God lives, but is the cunning-sort|
     v15                                |of wisdom which is among other things ruthlessly pragmatic, psychopathic, and diabolic. |
     V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, where jealousy and rivalry exist, there is turmoil, and every bad thing imaginable is done.|
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But the wisdom from the spiritual world where God lives is pure and innocent, then on top of that is|
     v17                                |peaceful, considerate, reasonable, full of mercy, and without pretense. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The end-result where everything turns out right has its origins in peace by those who put peace into|
     v18                                |practice.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||
    [ JAMES Chapter 3 has no footnotes ]

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 4  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Where do the long, drawn-out quarrels and fights among you come from? Is it not from the pleasurable|
     v 1                                |carnal impulses which are a component of your human nature, enlisted in a war against you? |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You desire but don’t have anything to show for it—murder and covet but don’t attain—fight and have long,|
     v 2                                |drawn-out quarrels—You don’t have on account of you not asking. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You ask and don’t receive because you ask with bad intentions, asking for something for the purpose of|
     v 3                                |spending it on your carnal impulses. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Spiritual adulterers, don’t you know that a close friend of the world (i.e. the ungodly society of mankind)|
     v 4                                |is pitted against God? So now, he who wishes he were the world’s close friend puts himself in a position|
     v 4                                |where he’s God’s enemy. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Or do you think that the verse of Scripture which says “The Spirit that has taken up residence in us|
     v 5                                |and among us jealously longs and desires for hearts turned towards Him” is a waste of time?|
 + N V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now the Bible lets us off the hook all the more; owing to this it says,|
 +PN V 6            SPACER_INTER_PROSE: ||
 +PN V 6                  VERSES_PROSE: |God takes a stance against the arrogant, proud, and haughty|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JAMES Chapter 5  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Come on now, you rich people who act like the stereotypical rich, weep and wail over the miseries that|
     v 1                                |assail you. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Your wealth has rotted and your fancy clothes have been eaten by moths. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Your hoard of gold and silver has corroded, and its corrosion will show you just how guilty you are and|
     v 3                                |eat you alive as though being burned at the stake: you’ve stashed valuables away in this era in which|
     v 3                                |God is doing the great things He promised He’d do. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Take a look—the wages which you’ve withheld from the workers scything your grain fields cry out, and|
     v 4                                |these outcries have secured the attention of the Great Unseen Army Chief of Staff, and He is favorably|
     v 4                                |disposed to wage war on the workers’ behalf. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You have lived the life of luxury in the midst of the going-ons of this life and have indulged in every|
     v 5                                |pleasure. You fattened your hearts in a day of slaughter (i.e., just like a cow is fed extra grain to|
     v 5                                |fatten it up right before it’s slaughtered, your heart has been fed and has become fat and is well-primed|
     v 5                                |to be slaughtered during this present cattle-slaughter season). |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You condemned—you MURDERED—the righteous. They don’t even try to fight you off.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So be patient, comrades, until the Lord appears on the scene. Take a look at how your typical farmer|
     v 7                                |awaits the valuable crop that the soil produces, how he applies patience through the course of it all,|
     v 7                                |ultimately getting the Planting Rains and the Harvesting Rains. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You too be patient, make your hearts resolute, because the Lord is getting closer and closer to coming.|
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Don’t groan at each other in exasperation, comrades, so that you not be judged. Take a look—the judge|
     v 9                                |is waiting for someone to give him the nod to take action. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |For example, comrades, take a look at the suffering of the prophets, who spoke with the mouth of the|
     v10                                |Lord. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |There you have it: blessed are they who endure. You heard about the endurance of Job and saw how the|
     v11                                |Lord’s dealings with him turned out, that He was full of pity and was compassionate too.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now first and foremost, my dear comrades, don’t swear oaths: don’t pledge any oath by the sky (including|
     v12                                |heaven itself) nor by the earth. Let a simple “yes” be your yes-answer, and simple “no” be your no-answer,|
     v12                                |in order not to incur a tremendous burden of guilt.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Is anyone among you enduring hardship?—Have him pray. Anyone cheerful?—Have him sing for joy. |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Anyone run-down with a malady of some sort?—Have him summon the church governing board, have them pray|
     v14                                |over him after rubbing oil on him (or coating him in oil) acting under the authority of the Lord, |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the prayer of faith will restore the health of the one who’s ill, and the Lord will get him back|
     v15                                |on his feet and going. And if he has committed sins, he’ll be forgiven.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Confess your sins out loud to each other, comrades, and pray for each other, in order to be healed. The|
     v16                                |prayer of a righteous man is capable of accomplishing a lot. |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Elijah was a person who experienced the same emotions that we do and prayed a tremendous prayer that|
     v17                                |it wouldn’t rain, and it didn’t rain all over the place for three and a half years. |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |He prayed again and the sky issued forth rain, and out of the ground sprouted the plants that the Earth|
     v18                                |produces.|
 +   V19              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My dear comrades: if any person should wander from the truth and someone were to get him back on track,|
     V20              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |let him know that the person who gets a sinner back on track and away from a path of wandering from the|
     v20                                |truth will rescue his psychological well-being (and perhaps even his very life) from waste, ruin, destruction,|
     v20                                |and worthlessness and covers a multitude of sins.|

 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |So seeing that Christ suffered in the flesh, you too arm yourselves (mentally speaking) for the same,|
     v 1                                |since he who’s suffered in the flesh has stopped sins from happening. |

     v 2                                |live your days out in the will of God. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact of the matter is, there’s been plenty of time to have acted out the yearnings of the heathen|
     v 3                                |nations to the nth degree, having followed a course of unrestrained indulgence in immoral, physical pleasures|
     v 3                                |(especially sexual ones); heated, passionate, over-the-top lusts and desires; drunkenness; wild partying;|
     v 3                                |parties centered around getting drunk; and idolatry—which is absolutely forbidden. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In regard to this, they think it’s weird that you don’t join them in rushing to the very same spigot|
     v 4                                |which is pouring out a shameless, wasted lifestyle, and you’re vilified for it— |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |They’ll have to cough up an answer for this and give it to Him who’s primed and ready to judge both kinds|
     v 5                                |of people, those who are spiritually alive and those who are spiritually dead. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |With this in mind, you see, a good-news message was evangelized to those who are spiritually dead, so|
     v 6                                |that while—sure—in their natural lives they’re held to a standard in accordance to human rules and expectations,|
     v 6                                |but on the other hand in their spiritual lives would live in accordance to God’s grace, plans, rules|
     v 6                                |and expectations.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paramount among all things is that the end is near, so keep your head screwed on tightly and control|
     v 7                                |yourselves so you’ll stay in the mode of offering up prayers. |

     v 8                                |over a good number of sins.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Be hospitable (i.e., be open to those who are different than yourselves) to one another without complaint.|

     v14                                |you. |
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But upon closer examination, make sure it’s not the case that any of you are suffering as a murderer,|

 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Simon Peter, servant and missionary of Jesus Christ:|

     v 3                                |been bestowed upon us all through the recognition and understanding of Him who called us by means of|
     v 3                                |His own glory and virtue. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Through this glory and virtue He has given the valuable, absolute-greatest promises to us, so that through|
     v 4                                |them you shoulder-to-shoulder participants would become partakers of His divine nature, having escaped|
     v 4                                |the corruption which is with the strong desires and lustful passions in the world-system which humans|
     v 4                                |created.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And for this very reason, get all over it and supply the moral virtue which is dearly needed in the application|
     v 5                                |of your faith, and the knowledge which is needed in the moral virtue, |

     v 6                                |in the endurance, |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |and the close friendship with your fellow man in the piety, and the love in the close friendship with|
     v 7                                |your fellow man. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |In fact, while these things exist in you and increase—as opposed to being idle or unproductive—they constitute|
     v 8                                |coming to the knowledge and understanding of our Lord Jesus Christ.|
 +   V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |When you get right down to it, the one who hasn’t gotten this is blind, not being able to see the big|
     v 9                                |picture, oblivious to the cleansing of the sins that he committed long ago. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All the more reason, comrades, to get on it and make sure your Christian walk is tied down; you see,|
     v10                                |by doing this, there’s no way at all that you’ll ever get off-track. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The fact is, this is the way that the access into the eternal kingdom (i.e., God’s involvement in our|
     v11                                |lives) of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ will be abundantly supplied to you.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Therefore I intend to constantly remind you of these things, although you’ve reached the point where|
     v12                                |you have firsthand knowledge and are established in the truth which is right in front of you. |
     V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But I consider it to be the right thing to do, to stir you up by giving you copious reminders for as|
     v13                                |long as I’m in this physical container of a body, |
     V14              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |seeing that the laying aside of my body is imminent, just as our Lord Jesus Christ made clear to me.|
     V15              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now I’ll urgently be about the business of having you constantly keep these memories alive after I depart|
     v15                                |from this life.|
 +   V16              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, we weren’t copying crafty, cunning myths when we made known to you the power and coming of our|
     v16                                |Lord Jesus Christ, but we happened to be eye-witnesses of that magnificence instead, |
     V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |seeing that he received honor and glory from God the Father in such majestic-sounding words delivered|
     v17                                |to him by the Magnificent Glory, “This is My Beloved Son, with whom I’ve been very pleased.” |
     V18              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |From out of the sky we heard the sounds of those words, after being brought up the holy mountain with|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JOHN1 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JOHN1 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That which was from day-one, that which we’ve heard, that which we’ve seen with our eyes, that which|
     v 1                                |we’ve beheld and our hands handled concerning the word of life— |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And the life was manifested, and we have beheld it and give an official report about it: we announce|
     v 2                                |to you the Eternal Life (i.e. that special fullness of life) which was with the Father and was manifested|
     v 2                                |to us. |
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |That which we’ve beheld and heard, we announce even to you, so that you would have fellowship with us,|
     v 3                                |but also that Our Fellowship would be with the Father and with His Son Jesus Christ. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |We’re writing these things to you so that your joy would attain its greatest extent.|
 +   V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |This is the very announcement which we heard from him and announce to you, that God is light and there|
     v 5                                |is not a single bit of darkness in Him. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to say that we have fellowship with Him and conduct our lives in the darkness, we would be|
     v 6                                |lying and not practicing the truth. |
     V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But if we were to conduct our lives in the light just as He is in the light, we would have fellowship|
     v 7                                |with one another, and the blood of His son Jesus would cleanse us from all sins. |
     V 8              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to say on a given occasion that we don’t have sin, we would be fooling ourselves and the truth|
     v 8                                |would not be in us. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to confess our sins, He’s faithful and always does the right thing so that He would forgive|
     v 9                                |us of our sins and would cleanse us from all unrighteousness. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to say on a given occasion that we’ve reached the point where we haven’t sinned, we’re making|
     v10                                |Him out to be a liar and His word (His system of thought) is not in us.|
 +   V--         SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||
    [ JOHN1 Chapter 1 has no footnotes ]

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JOHN1 Chapter 2  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |My children, I’m writing these things to you so that you wouldn’t sin. But if someone were to sin, we|
     v 1                                |have a Helper with the Father, righteous Jesus Christ. |
     V 2              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |And he is, by nature, the means of appeasement where our sin is concerned; not just where our sin is|
     v 2                                |concerned only but also where the sin of the entire world, the established order of humans, is concerned.|
     V 3              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If we were to keep His commandments, by this know that we have come to know and understand Him. |
     V 4              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The one who says, “I’ve come to know and understand Him,” but isn’t keeping His commandments: he’s a|
     v 4                                |liar, and the truth is not in him. |
     V 5              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |But on the other hand, if one were to keep His word, His system of thought, by doing this the love of|
     v 5                                |God has truly been brought to perfection. By this we know and understand that we are in Him. |
     V 6              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The one who’s making statements claiming to be dwelling in Him—that person is obligated to go through|
     v 6                                |a tour of conduct accordingly and that very person is obligated to be conducting his life in that manner.|
 +   V 7              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Beloved, I’m not writing to you a new, never-heard-of-before commandment, but rather an old commandment,|
     v 7                                |one which you’ve had continually from day-one. The Old Commandment is the train of thought which you’ve|
     v 7                                |heard. |

     v 5                                |but rather one which we’ve had from day-one—that we love one another. |

     v 8                                |instead. |
     V 9              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |All who are venturing beyond accepted teaching and are not remaining in the doctrine of Christ do not|
     v 9                                |have God. The one who remains in the teaching: this person has both the Father and the son. |
     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |If someone comes to you and doesn’t bring this doctrine of Christ with him, don’t take him into a home|
     v10                                |and don’t extend a greeting to him which makes him welcome. |
     V11              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |You see, the one who expresses a greeting to him which makes him welcome aids, abets, and is a fellow-participant|
     v11                                |in his deeds, which are evil.|
 +   V12              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |I have a lot to write to you about but decided not to on account of having to express my thoughts with|
     v12                                |pen and paper, but rather hope to appear to you in person and speak face-to-face, so that our joy would|
     v12                                |be filled to the fullest.|
 +   V13              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |The children spiritually-speaking of your fellow-chosen-of-God-woman greet you.|

 + N V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Jude, the servant of Jesus Christ and the brother of James:|

     v 4                                |into debauchery and denying the one master, our Lord Jesus Christ.|

     V10              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Now those people indeed bad-mouth things which they have no direct knowledge of, those whose understanding|
     v10                                |has a nature like ridiculous creatures; they’re being destroyed in these matters by their decadence.|

     v11                                |rebellion, they were destroyed.|

     v12                                |absolutely and completely dead and uprooted; |
